story:
When you are stuck inside the four walls of a hospital room for more days than you care to count, art can be a saving grace that speaks to your soul. 


In the past year, it has been my extreme blessing to paint murals for the Oncology unit at St. Joseph Regional Medical Center, in Mishawaka, Indiana.  When I first  began to paint here, I didn't realize how much this job would impact my life.  As I have watched cancer patients view my artwork, I have seen them gain hope, and determination to keep up the fight.  This experience has inspired me.  It has given me focus, and a vision for my future as an artist.  My desire is to continue to bring hope to Oncology patients through expressive art. 

My ambition is to continue painting inspirational murals for cancer patience throughout the U.S. in 2015.  Last August, in an effort to accomplish my goal, I purchased a 1973  Airstream Sovereign.  However, it was hit by a tornado and needs some work before it is road ready.


What We Need & What You Get

My goal is to raise $10,000 USD in order to make the repairs needed to the Airstream, and to purchase a used but reliable truck with the towing capacity needed to haul the Airstream.  Any extra money will used to purchase quality camera lenses for shooting artwork (hence the poor quality images), & a laser printer to enable me to make my own fine art prints.

So what level would you like to contribute at? Here are some examples of investment levels and what you get for your generosity! :

$25 - Set of 6 Fine Art Greeting Cards

This set of 6 cards, features 3 original designs.  All the cards are hand printed locally on a letterpress making each one an original piece of art. Give them away as a gift or frame them for your home or office.

$50 -"Lotus In Snow" print; 8x8

This is an original piece of art based on a mural I created at St. Joseph Regional Medical Center. The artwork reads;  "The lotus is a flower that is rooted at the bottom of miry water. It shows great determination as it forces it's way up through the darkness until it finally emerges into the sunlight and booms as a beautiful flower. The lotus flower becomes a symbol of perseverance, overcoming and survival as the miry water is often related to a dark trial in life. Encouragement is found in the hope that at the end, a person will be met with the joy of the sunshine and bloom as the beautiful lotus flower."
This print comes with an artist's statement making this a wonderful & unique gift for cancer survivors.

$100 - Limited Edition Print; 11x14

Receive an 11x14 fine art print of original artwork created special for the campaign.  This limited edition print is numbered and signed.  It comes with a special artist's statement making this a wonderful and unique gift for cancer survivors.

$500 - "In Loving Memory Of _________"

Dedicate a mural in honor of the memory of a loved one, and encourage others in their battle against cancer through your contribution.  
"In loving memory of _________" will be painted onto a mural at an oncology facility.
As my personal "thank you", you will also receive a fine art print inspired by the dedicated mural along with a unique artist's statement.

$4,000 - A Dedicated Mural

One  great way to say "thank you" to the exceptional care that was received from a facility, or to preserve the memory of someone you love, is by the donation of an inspirational mural.
I will work with you and the hospital/care center of your choice to design and create an original mural (up to 100 sq ft) in dedication to you/your love one/the staff's exceptional care.  

As my personal "thank you", you will also receive a painting inspired by the dedicated mural along with a unique artist's statement.


The Impact

For people who are sick, it is important that they get up out of bed when they are able, walk around, and have a renewed hope, and inspiration for life.  Art can do that.

For people who have lost someone dear to their heart, it is important that their memory live on, that others remember their life and are inspired.  Art can do that too.

above: A Three Stranded Cord; a memorial piece to honor the victims of a shooting. The words "love, hope & unity" are three strands that together make up the strength of the community.
Art can offer hope.  It is an inspiration of life.  It can sooth the soul & offer healing to the hurting.

Other Ways You Can Help

Looking for other ways you can help?

Help spread the word.  Can you commit to share this campaign on your facebook page, email people you know who would be interested to learn about what I am doing, or help get me in front of a group of people who may be interested in investing in my plan?

Not only am I looking to raise the funds I need to start creating murals on the road, I'm also always on the lookout for places to paint.  If you know of someone who might be interested in having an original mural painted let them know about my work.

Learn more about me, and my artwork please visit my website at www.thefibernest.com
story_txt:
When you are stuck inside the four walls of a hospital room for more days than you care to count, art can be a saving grace that speaks to your soul.  

In the past year, it has been my extreme blessing to paint murals for the Oncology unit at St. Joseph Regional Medical Center, in Mishawaka, Indiana.  When I first  began to paint here, I didn't realize how much this job would impact my life.  As I have watched cancer patients view my artwork, I have seen them gain hope, and determination to keep up the fight.  This experience has inspired me.  It has given me focus, and a vision for my future as an artist.  My desire is to continue to bring hope to Oncology patients through expressive art.  
My ambition is to continue painting inspirational murals for cancer patience throughout the U.S. in 2015.  Last August, in an effort to accomplish my goal, I purchased a 1973  Airstream Sovereign.  However, it was hit by a tornado and needs some work before it is road ready.




  What We Need & What You Get My goal is to raise $10,000 USD in order to make the repairs needed to the Airstream, and to purchase a used but reliable truck with the towing capacity needed to haul the Airstream.  Any extra money will used to purchase quality camera lenses for shooting artwork (hence the poor quality images), & a laser printer to enable me to make my own fine art prints.
So what level would you like to contribute at? Here are some examples of investment levels and what you get for your generosity! :



$25 - Set of 6 Fine Art Greeting Cards
This set of 6 cards, features 3 original designs.  All the cards are hand printed locally on a letterpress making each one an original piece of art. Give them away as a gift or frame them for your home or office.





$50 -"Lotus In Snow" print; 8x8 
This is an original 
piece of art based on a mural I created at St. Joseph Regional Medical 
Center. The artwork reads;  "The lotus is a flower that is rooted at the 
bottom of miry water.  It 
shows great determination as it forces it's way up through the darkness 
until it finally emerges into the sunlight and booms as a beautiful 
flower. The lotus flower becomes a symbol of perseverance, 
overcoming and survival as the miry water is often related to a dark 
trial in life.  Encouragement is found in the hope that at the end, a 
person will be met with the joy of the sunshine and bloom as the 
beautiful lotus flower."This print comes with an artist's statement making this a wonderful & unique gift for cancer survivors.


$100 - Limited Edition Print; 11x14Receive an 11x14 fine art print of original artwork created special for the campaign.  This limited edition print is numbered and signed.  It comes with a special artist's statement making this a wonderful and unique gift for cancer survivors.
$500 - "In Loving Memory Of _________"
Dedicate a mural in honor of the memory of a loved one, and encourage others in their battle against cancer through your contribution.  "In loving memory of _________" will be painted onto a mural at an oncology facility. As my personal "thank you", you will also receive a fine art print inspired by the dedicated mural along with a unique artist's statement.
$4,000 - A Dedicated Mural
One  great way to say "thank you" to the exceptional care that was received from a facility, or to preserve the memory of someone you love, is by the donation of an inspirational mural.I will work with you and the hospital/care center of your choice to design and create an original mural (up to 100 sq ft) in dedication to you/your love one/the staff's exceptional care.  As my personal "thank you", you will also receive a painting inspired by the dedicated mural along with a unique artist's statement.

  The Impact For people who are sick, it is important that they get up out of bed when they are able, walk around, and have a renewed hope, and inspiration for life.  Art can do that.

For people who have lost someone dear to their heart, it is important that their memory live on, that others remember their life and are inspired.  Art can do that too.above: A Three Stranded Cord; a memorial piece to honor the victims of a shooting. The words "love, hope & unity" are three strands that together make up the strength of the community.Art can offer hope.  It is an inspiration of life.  It can sooth the soul & offer healing to the hurting.
  Other Ways You Can Help Looking for other ways you can help?
Help spread the word.  Can you commit to share this campaign on your facebook 
page, email people you know who would be interested to learn about what I am
 doing, or help get me in front of a group of people who may be interested in investing in my plan?
Not only am I looking to raise the funds I need to start creating murals on the road, I'm also always on the lookout for places to paint.  If you know of someone who might be interested in having an original mural painted let them know about my work.
Learn more about me, and my artwork please visit my website at www.thefibernest.com

story:
Hi,

My name is Lawrence and I'm an artist currently living and working in Taichung, Taiwan. Welcome to my Indiegogo page!

What is Münster?

I've been working on the first book of a wordless novel series for the past 6 months. This project is called Münster and book 1 is now finished! The book consists of 126 pencil drawings which depict a historical event that took place in the city of Münster, Westphalia during the 1530s.

A general overview of the event can be found here http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M%C3%BCnster_Rebellion and for those that are more interested there's a great podcast titled PROPHETS OF DOOM by Dan Carlin http://www.dancarlin.com/disp.php/hharchive

The Breakdown

I'm using Indiegogo as a means through which to launch my book. This project has taken me a long time and now it's time to get it out there for people to see.

The way it works is really simple. Fund my project, and I'll send you a signed first edition of my book.

For those willing to spend a bit more, I will also be offering Medium Perks where you can pick up either an original drawing or an editioned print of one of my drawings to go along with the book. All prints are editions of 10 and are printed on high quality paper with archival inks that are guaranteed for over 70 years.

To cap it off, I will also be offering a Commission Perk where I will work with the individual backer on a composition for a portrait which I will then draw. The format for this will be A2 (16.5X23.4 inches/ 42cmX59cm). More on this in the Perk description!

Why Buy My Work?

I currently work as an English teacher here in Taiwan while simultaneously keeping disciplined studio hours for my drawing. My hope is that each year I can slowly start to teach less and make more money through my art. This is what I love doing and I hope to one day do this full time! If you like the work I do and would like to own some of it, please contribute! Also, if you have friends who you think would be interested, please share!


Update!

4 more days to go! I've put my latest drawing up for sale as a print! It's pictured below. Title: BEFORE THE LAW. Dimensions 42cmX59cm. Grab your copy along with the book for $130. For what inspired this piece read: http://www.kafka-online.info/before-the-law.html


The Goods

Check out the different prints and drawings I'm offering!


(above)The Freeing of the Nuns Print (59cmX42cm). Available with the book for $130.

(above) Mutiny at the Falls Print (59cmX42cm). Available with the book for $130.


(above)The Parade Print (37cmX21cm). Available with the book for $70.


(above) The Lumberjacks Print (42cmX59cm). Available with the book for $130.


(above) Boys on the Patio Print (42cmX59cm). Available with the book for $130.


(above) Portrait of Violet Print (42cmX59cm). Interested in this print? Please get in contact with me. I took it off the perks to make room for some drawings. Price is $130, which includes the book.


(above) Portrait of Will Print (42cmX59cm). Interested in this print? Please get in contact with me. I took it off the perks to make room for some drawings. Price is $130, which includes the book.


(above) The Workshop Print (42cmX59cm). Interested in this print? Please get in contact with me. I took it off the perks to make room for some drawings. Price is $130, which includes the book.



(above)THE WOLF PACK Print (16cmX20cm). Available with the book for $35.

(above) SHIPWRECK Print (16cmX20cm). Available with the book for $35.



(above) STRANGE GROWTH Print (16cmX20cm). Available with the book for $35.

(above) King of the Hill Print(16cmX20cm). Available with the book for $35.

(above)Tree House Print (16cmX20cm). Available with the book for $35.

For more on my art, give the dancing man a click at http://lawrencekeaty.com

story:
Washing D'Arty Linen

In Veli, in the southern Indian port city of Kochi there is a common facility for washer-men called DHOBI KHANA. This is managed by the washer men's co-operative called the Vannar Sangham. All together 60 washer- men wash 1000 pieces of clothing and bed linen in a day. Since Kochi is a popular tourist destination, most of the dirty laundry consists of linen collected from the local home stays and hotels.

The mammoth task of soaking, washing, and rinsing is carried out manually and is an extremely laborious process. The washer-men start working every day at 5.00A.M and usually work till 5 pm in the evening. The washing is done in a traditional manner in a barrack housing 42 cubicles of roughly 8 feet by 10 feet each. The cubicle is divided into two cement water tanks –one about 3 feet tall along the back wall and the second filled with about one and a half feet water in which they stand and do the washing. While being a labor intense process, the current setup is also causing a lot of health issues for the washer-men. The Vannar Sangham is looking to mechanise the facility in order to provide working conditions for the washer-men, but the lack of funds is limiting them from keep pace with the changing times.

Kochi is a tourist town, dotted with home stays. There is therefore no dearth of work for the Dhobi Khana but the younger generation considers this a menial occupation and is seeking employment in other professions. Some have even moved to other towns. 

The community has self –organised into a co-operative which  is an important factor as it has created an effective eco-system. I believe it is important for the co-operative to sustain itself and continue functioning. If the co-operative breaks up, without doubt smaller laundries will spring up to supply the demand leading to competitive practices for individual profit. The current members of the co-operative who are mainly of advanced years are aware of the benefits of working as a collective. Apart from sharing an emotional bond that goes back centuries, they also benefit from the collective bank account -the managing committee in consultation with them provides monetary support for medical /funerary and other emergencies from this.

I am executing a project titled 'Washing D'Arty Linen' at Kochi as part of 'Critical Juncture,'* which is a joint Indian-Polish art exhibition and a collateral of the Kochi-Muziris Biennale. Through this project, I attempt to foreground the washer-men co-operative's significance in the exhibition space.  It is in fact a collaboration between the Vannar Sangham and my mock corporate enterprise UNICELL. I will give them the space allocated to me in the exhibition in which they will hang the linen that is washed at the Dhobi Khana thus making themselves visible. Incidentally, since this project takes place during the Biennale, the linen will mostly be of the art tourist.

The objective of this project is to raise funds to procure an industrial washing machine and a hydro extractor to be installed at the Dhobi Khana. This washing machine and hydro extractor will then be donated to the co-operative.

* 'Critical Juncture' : Curated by Visual anthropologist and curator Dr. Neelima Jeychandran and UK-based Polish artist-curator, Magda Fabianczyk, this event will bring together six Polish and five  Indian artists. While the works by artists from Poland and India are informed by this specific concept, they also explore other contemporary political and social issues such as the relationship between the individual, group and society, mechanisms of exclusion and forms of self-organisation. http://www.criticaljuncture.info/

History of Vannar Sangham

Vannar Sangham ( a registered society of  the Vannan community )is a co-operative of washer men in Kochi. They are a community engaged in this occupation from circa 1640 and are migrants from Tuticorin and Tirunelveli in Tamil Nadu brought here first by the Portuguese and then the second batch was brought by the Dutch from Kannanur and Tellicherry in 1849 to wash their army's laundry.

Vannar Sangham assumed legal status in 1977 and is currently led by Mr. Sathish (secretary of the Sangham) and C Shanmugaraj (president of Vannar Sangham. The Greater Cochin Development Authority built the existing structures in 1976 on 2.8 acres of land in lieu of the 11 acres it took from the community to build a stadium. The Cochin Municipal Corporation owns the land that the Dhobi Khana stands on. The process of transfer of the land to the co-operative has been initiated by the current Secretary.

What is UNICELL Public Works Cell?

UNICELL is a project I started in 2004. UNICELL is short for unicellular. It is a single-person organisation run under an assumed identity of a corporate. UNICELL comments on concerns of contemporary urbanity in India, utilizing creativity and design. It creates  art projects that seek to make interventions in urban space, by designing and producing objects that are functional as well as aesthetic. Unicell mimics many of the absurdities of government bureaucracy. Satire and humour is the mode of operation in most of the projects. 

I strongly believe in the relevance of art practice especially in contemporary society and its connectivity and relation to real life issues. Accordingly, my art practice over the past decade or so has catered to explicit socio-political agendas.

About Me:

I am an artist and an art educator who is currently living and working in New Delhi, India. I am an Associate Professor at the Department of Art Design and Performing Art in the School of Humanities and Social Sciences, Shiv Nadar University. I believe art is a tool for social transformation and an equally strong agent for political action. Most of my projects aim to provide discursive platforms for addressing contemporary urban issues.  I am the co-founder of the Bombay-based artist collective called “Open Circle” that sought to engage with contemporary socio-political issues by I integrating theory with practice. As a core member of the “Open Circle” initiative, I organized study circles, public 

actions, protests, and other interventionist actions in which I developed various strategies of art making to generate awareness about important social and cultural issues. For instance, I conducted a series of workshops and interventions in support of the Narmada Bacchao Andolan, a peoples movement against the environmental impacts of Sardar Sarovar—a  mega dam project, which also resulted in the displacement of underprivileged communities from the area. Having  worked with various organisations and unions on issues regarding inequitable development and displacement of urban poor in Bombay,  I have also  convened and curated numerous international events, screenings, and exhibitions, and had the opportunity to serve as the co-convener and facilitator of the Culture Committee in the World Social Forum (2004), Mumbai, India.  I have a Masters in Sculpture from M. S. U Baroda (1988-1990) and an undergraduate degree in Sculpture from Sir J. J. School of Arts in 1988.  I was a resident fellow at Rijksakademie in Amsterdam (1998-2000).

Costs and Funding:

About Five Lakhs Fifty Thousand Rupees is required for the realisation of the project, which in turn will help in the mechanization of the Dhobikhana. This is possible only through crowd funding as the requirement of funds is much beyond the production budget allocated per artist for the project Critical Juncture.

One Washing machine and one Extractor will be required to partially meet the needs of the co-operative

47,850

3,77,850
added to this are 

Costsof interstate transportation and installation of the machines Rs.50,000/-

Fees of , and processing fees of the partner institution 1 Shanthi Road for accepting the funds, Rs. 82,500/-

making and disseminating the rewards for the supporters Rs. 40,000/-

Totaling Rupees 5,50,000/-

Impact and Sustainability

1. The mechanisation will allow the community to cope the arduous task and long working hours of soaking, rinsing in water and washing by hands with detergents and bleaching agents. It will also help in keeping up  with the demands of the tourist industry of Kochi.

2. Charges (per hour) will be collected by the co-operative from the washer- men depending on the usage.

3. A separate bank account will be opened to deposit the charges collected.

4. The funds collected as charges will be used for the maintenance of the machines and may be to put aside some amount towards a pension scheme of the community.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute but believe  in the project please urge your friends and relatives to support the campaign. Indiegogo has share tools that easily enable you do this

story:
WHAT YOU'RE SUPPORTING:

In June, artists from around the world will converge in rural Latvia at the Pedvale Open-Air Art Museum for the 7th International Conference on Contemporary Cast Iron Art.

This conference will explore the conceptual and aesthetic context of sculptural iron casting and its effect on contemporary art, forms of ritual, and the transformation of landscape.  It is a platform to share ideas, processes, and work, while contributing to the aesthetic and cultural dialogue of sculptural iron casting.

There's a group of Minnesota-based artists heading to Latvia to participate in the cultural exchange and to work on creative projects during the conference.  We need your help to make these projects happen!


WHO WE ARE:

The 5 Minnesota-based artists & their projects you're supporting...


WHY DONATE:

These creative projects are individually funded, and we're looking at expenses of $3,000+/person to participate.  Your support through this campaign helps to subsidize a huge portion of the expense ($15,000+!) to get the 5 artists to Latvia and make these projects happen.

The projects contribute to an international dialogue of sculptural iron casting, and you can help fuel this creative art movement!


WHAT YOU GET:

These gifts are all cultural reflections of the connections between Minnesota and Latvia.  The cast iron sculptures are custom made and cast by the artists you're supporting!


If you are unable to contribute, but love our project, please share this project with your friends and family!  By sharing, you're helping to expand opportunities for creative art projects.  Thank you!
story_txt:
WHAT YOU'RE SUPPORTING:In June, artists from around the world will converge in rural Latvia at the Pedvale Open-Air Art Museum for the 7th International Conference on Contemporary Cast Iron Art.This conference will explore the conceptual and aesthetic context of sculptural iron casting and its effect on contemporary art, forms of ritual, and the transformation of landscape.  It is a platform to share ideas, processes, and work, while contributing to the aesthetic and cultural dialogue of sculptural iron casting.There's a group of Minnesota-based artists heading to Latvia to participate in the cultural exchange and to work on creative projects during the conference.  We need your help to make these projects happen!WHO WE ARE:The 5 Minnesota-based artists & their projects you're supporting...




WHY DONATE:These creative projects are individually funded, and we're looking at expenses of $3,000+/person to participate.  Your support through this campaign helps to subsidize a huge portion of the expense ($15,000+!) to get the 5 artists to Latvia and make these projects happen.The projects contribute to an international dialogue of sculptural iron casting, and you can help fuel this creative art movement!WHAT YOU GET:These gifts are all cultural reflections of the connections between Minnesota and Latvia.  The cast iron sculptures are custom made and cast by the artists you're supporting!








If you are unable to contribute, but love our project, please share this project with your friends and family!  By sharing, you're helping to expand opportunities for creative art projects.  Thank you!

story:
The Book


We collect together in a net is an artist's book by Kerry Downey, which will be published this June by Wendy's Subway, a Brooklyn-based non-profit reading room, writing space, and independent publisher. Designed by Erik Freer and edited by Rachel Valinsky, the publication will include 14 full color reproductions of recent work, alongside texts by a handful of incredible art writers: Jaime Shearn Coan, Jeanne Vaccaro, Ryan Wong, and Layla Zami.

We collect together in a net assembles a series of monotypes that have been transformed through highly physical printed and manual processes (Chine-collé, embossment, rubbing, sanding). These many forms of contact bring attention to the materiality of paper, and draw parallels between paper’s surface and our skin. Skin’s porousness acts as a threshold, between the personal and the social, the psychological and the embodied. Like a net, it contains and disperses, and locates our entanglements in the world. The net is a central figure in Downey’s interdisciplinary practice, and reflects on the interdependent structures that produce the many ways we inhabit our bodies and access forms of power.

This series of works on paper was produced at Robert Blackburn Printmaking Workshop, a co-operative printmaking workspace. In close collaboration with each writer, the book’s designer, and the editorial team, they are collected in this new artist’s book. Like much of Kerry’s work, the publication offered an opportunity to explore how collaboration across these different modes is possible, and to create occasions for relationships and conversations to grow out of the work itself.

Book Details

Kerry Downey
We collect together in a net
Softcover, Sewn binding
9.5 x 13 inches, 44 pages
14 color plates
Edition of 500 (50 signed)
ISBN: 978-1-7327086-2-4
Release: July 2019
Retail cost: $30

 

About Kerry Downey
 

Kerry Downey (b.1979, Ft. Lauderdale) is an interdisciplinary artist and educator based in New York City. Downey’s work explores relationality through the multitude of ways we inhabit our bodies and access forms of power. Downey works primarily in video with a practice that includes printmaking, drawing, writing, and performance. They’ve recently had a solo show at CAVE in Detroit and two-person shows at Knockdown Center and 20|20 Gallery in New York City. They have exhibited at the Queens Museum, Flushing, NY; the Hessel Museum at Bard College, Annandale, NY; The Drawing Center, New York, NY; Cooper Cole, Toronto, CA, and Taylor Macklin, Zurich, CH.  Downey is a recipient of the Joan Mitchell Foundation Emerging Artist Grant and Foundation for Contemporary Arts Grant.  Artist-in-residencies include Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture, Madison, ME; Triangle Arts Association, Brooklyn, NY; SHIFT at EFA Project Space, New York, NY; the Drawing Center’s Open Sessions, New York, NY; Real Time and Space, Oakland, CA; and the Vermont Studio Center, Johnson, VT. Downey participated in the Queer/Art/Mentorship program in 2013. 

 

What We Need & What You Get


Our $3,000 goal is to match a recent grant Downey received from the Joan Mitchell Foundation in order to support this project. We hope to print 500 copies of the book. We need your help to print! Wendy’s Subway is a small non-profit with an ambitious publishing program which highlights the work of visual and performance artists, and writers working across disciplines.

By supporting this campaign, you're supporting independent publishing, the artist's project, and the writers contributing to this publication, as well as the collaborative vision that has guided the editorial and design process for this book from the outset.

Wendy’s Subway and Kerry Downey are offering a number of perks for support to this campaign:

  • Pre-order the book here today and you’ll be the first to receive it!
  • Or pre-order one of 50 signed copies of the book.
  • Receive a limited edition Risograph print featuring artwork included in the publication.
  • Acquire a unique monotype prints by Kerry Downey. Each monotype features different materials and techniques, including paint, collage, Chine collé, and photo transfer on paper, and exists in a number of sizes (11 x 15 inches; 11 x 16 inches; 22 x 30 inches 24 x 36 inches; 30 x 40 inches). Monotypes are available at four price points: $200, $300, $400, and $500. See the links below for available works.

View available monotypes here.

 

The Impact

 

Your contribution goes a long way! Wendy’s Subway is a small non-profit with an ambitious publishing program which highlights and supports the work of visual and performance artists, and writers working across disciplines. Support independent publishing by pre-ordering a book straight from the publisher. Your contribution also supports Kerry Downey’s artistic practice, and a project undertaken over the course of the past year to make paper and develop prints for the publication, their first major book!

 

Other Ways You Can Help
 

  • Spread the word about Kerry Downey's publication!
  • Attend the book launch in late June.
  • Tell your local bookstore and library to stock some copies.
  • Take a look at Wendy's Subway's publication catalogue.

story:
THE ISSUE

Working in the Performing Arts means long hours, unpredictable working patterns, last minute recruitment practices, regular evening, weekend and bank holiday work, regular travel and low earnings. This is even harder to sustain as a parent.

'This is a conversation that is long overdue' Vicky Featherstone

In 2015 an independent survey of over 500 parents in the creative industries conducted by Laura Wells, found that 74% of respondents had missed out on work due to childcare issues. 

Due to the lack of provision for the self-employed creative there is often little choice over which job to take or when to work if practitioners are to make ends meet and provide for their families. Most face significant difficulties accessing affordable, flexible childcare. Many parents in the performing arts industry – particularly female and single parents – are dropping out of the workforce as they cannot afford to continue their profession.

Childcare, support and understanding should not be a privilege, they should be a given, in our industry as in others. It is not acceptable that childbirth should be the beginning of one life and the end of another.

This is not an issue limited to gender, class, race or even whether you are a parent of not, it is about the future of the Arts.

‘Parents in the Arts need to stage a childcare revolution’ Lyn Gardner

WHAT WE NEED 

Following the launch our aim is to raise enough money to continue researching the reality facing parents in our Industries and find sustainable solutions.

£7000 will help us take the next crucial steps:

Next 6 months:

  • Host at least 2 Open Space style meetings, one in London and at least one at a regional venue
  • Develop the partnerships we have already established and continue to build new ones
  • Develop our website to become an online resource for parents and employers.
  •  Set up as a charity so we can access funding to work on our long term goals.
Next Year:
  • Campaign for an affordable drop in creche in London's West End or Southbank
  • Lobby flagship Theatres across to the UK to provide childcare facilities
  • Ensure that pregnancy isn't a barrier to working
  • Establish 'back to work' schemes for parents 
  • Establish Best Practice and Guidelines for production companies and theatres 

We are a small team taking on a huge project and in a small time we already have achieved more than we could have imagined. In the interests of time management we will endeavour to thank everyone in electronic form for your contribution but we hope you'll understand that time is at a premium and there is a lot of work to be done on this. 

ABOUT US

We are Cassie Raine and Anna Ehnold-Danailov, co-founders of PIPA. We set up the campaign group in 2015 in response to our respective experiences trying to continue our professions we had developed for over 10 years before having children. The PIPA Launch at The Young Vic in October 2015 saw over 400 people (and 70 children) eager to start this dialogue and fight for their rights. The campaign has gathered unprecedented momentum over the past 5 months and we have now been joined by Claire Wyatt and Adam Burns. The campaign is now backed by Equity, Stage Directors UK The Musicians’ Union, ITC, BECTU, SMA, ALD, TUC, SNDT and Family Arts Campaign.

PRESS

Here is a selection of press about the campaign. For more information about us please visit our website: www.pipacampiagn.com

The Stage - 16th October

The Guardian - 13th October

The Guardian - 16th October

The Stage - 1st October

The Independent - 15th October

story:
"The mountain as metaphor looms large in the lives of marginalized people, people whose bones get crushed in the grind of capitalism, patriarchy, white supremacy. How many of us have struggled up the mountain, measured ourselves against it, failed up there, lived its shadow? We’ve hit our heads on glass ceilings, tried to climb the class ladder, lost fights against assimilation, scrambled toward the phantom called normality."

- Exile & Pride, Eli Clare

 

What is 'Claimed Pastures'?

Claimed Pastures Is a photographic series i've been preparing for, which seeks to document and explore the complex and diverse queer identities that exist within rural areas. Claimed pastures sets out to tell stories of LGBTQ people underrepresented in mainstream culture and arts, broaden our understanding of where Queer people exist & flourish, and explore how our cultural & natural worlds affect our identity work/expressions of Queerness. 

This project stems from a desire to look at the ways in which LGBTQ culture and identity play out in different areas and what barriers exist that prevent some folks from entering/living in the urban areas that we know as Queer hubs.

This project is not restricted to any population size (or lack there of). Rather, it defines rural as any space that holds stigma as being uncultured, uneducated, or unrecognized. It will focus on areas that may lack visibility, resources, or recognition as a space for Queer people to inhabit. And it will highlight how these spaces uniquely affect people's identity work, how they express their queerness, and how they interact with, deviant from, or rely on their communities. 

And in a time of great political turmoil & uncertainty, and in a time where many cities are becoming unaffordable for many folks, we will seek to highlight spaces and organizations that exist as Queer hubs/resource centers outside of urban areas. 

This project will also seek to take an intersectional approach & will reach out to a large range of individuals who may also face challenges based on race, class, ability, etc. 

On the Road

I am heading out on the road in June 2017, for 1-2 months, traveling through the Northwest and beyond. During this time I will be exploring new communities and their environments, meeting numerous individuals to interview & photograph, and documenting my journey. I will be traveling in my trusty old truck packed with blankets, poetry, and photo equipment. I'll be staying with friends (or friends of friends) whenever possible, and spending nights in the back of the truck when need be. 

Challenges Ahead

As with any photo project, there will be challenges along the way. 

Meeting People to Photograph: Meeting LGBTQ folks in rural areas — at first glance — seems like an almost impossible task. But in the months prior to this trip, I will be connecting with as many people as possible to get in touch with friends of friends, family members, etc, to create as many leads as I can. There is a large issue of trust and vulnerability involved here, and not everyone I meet will want to be photographed or even be a part of this project.  and although not everyone I meet will want to be photographed, I will still plan on meeting everyone I can to at least hear their story. 

Film Logistics & Production: Shipping. Printing. Scanning. Etc. While I'm on the road, I will be working with a photo-lab in Idaho that I have a long-standing relationship with. Thanks to your donations, I will be able to safely ship the film to them to avoid any potentially destructive happening to them. Once there, they will handle the initial processing, scanning, and archiving of the film - allowing me not only to collect stable, developed film at the end of the trip, but also view scanned copies of my work while on the road.

With Your Support

If I have the pleasure of receiving your support, I'll be able to buy myself a new camera and buy the necessary film. I will also be able to pay for the processing & shipping of the film as I go on this journey. Finally, you will be helping me cover day to day expenses such as gas, food, and the ability to take a break from my day job for a few weeks in order to complete this project. 

Every donation, large or small, is deeply appreciated and important for keeping us on the road, making art, and sharing people's stories. Even just $10 will allow us to put a few more gallons of gas in the car, take us a few more miles down the road, and a little closer to our goal of raising awareness about underrepresented communities.

Cost Estimates:

New Camera               $750

Film + Developing     $500

Travel Expenses        $1000

Publishing/Showing  $500

Extra Materials/Equipment    $250

 

Other Ways to Help

Just as important as making a donation is helping us to spread the word about our project. Please share on social media, send an email or text, tell a friend, whatever it takes, please help us to let people know about this project and make some noise.

You can follow the progress through Instagram, Tumblr, or finding me on Facebook. 

Also, don't forget to use Indiegogo's social media sharing tools after you make your donation, shout your support from the rooftops, we're proud to have you on-­board as a supporter, you should be too!
____________________________________________________________________________

Disclaimer & Last Thoughts

Although I consider myself a member of the queer & trans community with rural routes — I am also white and fairly middle class. I recognize that many of the people and communities I may document are ones I am not a part of. I want to make sure to do this project in the most respectful and least problematic way possible, and give care & solidarity to people who's intersectional identities make them vulnerable to discrimination, exploitation, and even physical danger.  This project is not about me, it is about the people in it. So please, if anyone has any insight or concern about this project, do not hesitate to contact me. I am always learning & unlearning, and we are all in this together. 

 

Artist Bio

Photo by Raven Smith

Tay Sanders is an artist and photographer from Kennewick, WA. They earned their B.A. in Media Disparity, an interdisciplinary degree focusing on journalism, photography & critical media theory from Western Washington University. Their photography, in a broad sense, looks at the ways in which our natural and cultural worlds affect our identity work, our sense of home, and the norms we both cling to and deviate from. 

** Trans | Witch | Bumpkin | Femme **

<3

Big Thank you to Artist Trust as well! For getting the ball rolling for this project.

story:
JXTA Abroad

As a part of preparing young people to work in the field of Contemporary Art, this summer Juxtaposition Arts is sending two young apprentices, Ysabella Johnson and Samie Johnson (no relation), to study abroad in Europe. Ysabella Johnson is a student at the University of Minnesota studying Fine Arts and Samie Johnson is a student at Minneapolis Community and Technical College studying Community Development. They both work part time as assistant muraliats and show their work across the twin cities. This trip abroad coincides with two important arts events in Europe, Documenta 14 and the Venice Biennale. Ysa and Samie have shown themselves to be consistent and thoughtful emerging artists and the opportunity to see and experience contemporary art at these globally important venues is sure to inspire some amazing things from them both.

 

These events occur simultaneously only once a decade, so this summer offers Ysa and Samie a unique opportunity to see a large range of art produced by some of this century's most significant artists from across the world. It also provides them an opportunity to meet other working artists and reflect on the work that they themselves are making in relationship to an international community of cultural producers. They will be traveling to Kassel, Munich, and Bavaria in Germany and Balzano and Venice in Italy. Your contribution will support this unique learning opportunity by off setting costs of travel within Europe, lodging, and per diem's. 

 

The cost to send one apprentice is $3279. We have successfully raised enough to cover flights but would like to raise an additional $3,000 to cover lodging, passport fees, Eurorail passes, meals and materials. Your generous support will help get us there! We appreciate the generous community of supporters who have gotten us to this point and will value a donation of any value from $1 to $3000. 

 

 For our larger financial donors, there are creative perks!!! For a contribution of $50, Ysa and Samie will send a digital artwork made in each of the five cities they travel to. For a contribution of $100 they will mail you two handmade postcards during their travel; and for a contribution of $150+ they will send you a portfolio of 10 limited edition prints they they will complete over the course of their trip.

 

All of our supporters will be able to keep up with what Ysa and Samie are up to via their travel blog which will go live the week of June 13. And, if you can't contribute financially, you can contribute by sharing this campaign with others through social media or email. 

 

Thank you for your generosity!
story_txt: JXTA AbroadAs a part of preparing young people to work in the field of Contemporary Art, this summer Juxtaposition Arts is sending two young apprentices, Ysabella Johnson and Samie Johnson (no relation), to study abroad in Europe. Ysabella Johnson is a student at the University of Minnesota studying Fine Arts and Samie Johnson is a student at Minneapolis Community and Technical College studying Community Development. They both work part time as assistant muraliats and show their work across the twin cities. This trip abroad coincides with two important arts events in Europe, Documenta 14 and the Venice Biennale. Ysa and Samie have shown themselves to be consistent and thoughtful emerging artists and the opportunity to see and experience contemporary art at these globally important venues is sure to inspire some amazing things from them both. These events occur simultaneously only once a decade, so this summer offers Ysa and Samie a unique opportunity to see a large range of art produced by some of this century's most significant artists from across the world. story:
Introduction:

 

Hi I'm Mark. I'm a father, a husband, a self proclaimed foodie and adventurer and an amateur photographer and painter. 

I want to inspire you through my original art to send us on The Great Italian Truffle Hunt!

People who know me know I love to try new things and get inspired by those moments. I will create some new art for you!

I picked up the artists paintbrush 2 years ago and haven't put it down since!

I was trying to surprise my wife for our anniversary and I painted a picture of our favorite spot. It was a memorable trip where we we enjoyed exploring the amalfi coast of Italy meeting interesting people, amazing sights and it's actually where I proposed to her at the edge of Mediterranean ocean with our feet in the water in Positano Italy. My painting inspired from that trip is shown above. It was my very first. Since then I have improved and painted from my little painting room in Nova Scotia Canada. I really get inspired from culinary adventures or experiences from traveling. When I was in Asia I explored such great foods, ingredients, I went on a cooking course, bought some canvases and some paint and brushes rented a moped, met some french dudes and spent a week painting and teaching then to paint all from our daily adventures. When Dee I are travelling we always uncover some of the most interesting people, stories, coffee's , foods, flavors and colorful experiences. We have always wanted to go Truffle hunting in Italy and I just know I will be inspired by this trip.    

Join me on my adventure and take home a piece of my art!

 

What We Need & What You Get

So in order to take on this inspirational culinary artistic expedition we are asking for some financial assistance  We will need money for travel, painting supplies, accommodations  etc. We will need to fly there, rent a car, head to the back roads, attend a truffle festival  get educated, meet the locals, learn about truffle hunting, befriend a hunter or farmer and a dog or two and start digging. The best adventures have a destination and the rest is a journey. Any assistance would be appreciated.

We figure it will cost approximately $5000 for ten days of truffle adventure.

And for your donation I am offering you some of my already inspired artwork! Please see some of the inspired works I have on display!

We hope to also offer a print or two of the inspired new art and even a signed original or two  for some lucky funders!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help financially that's OK too but please help get out the word and make some noise about this and maybe this inspires you too!

Remember to use the indiegogo share tools too

Thanks for your support!

Mark & Dee

story:
A photo series by Shane LaVancher

Dedicated to Nicholas Todisco - 1937-2012

 

Much like the recent photo series of 2012 "Creatures", this new series "Machines" will examine the human condition of mental evolution. The question "Are we ancient hardware running advanced software?" 

Welcome to the post-human age. It is no longer the realm of speculative fantasy, or a curious vision into the future of mankind. The technologies that were once so unimaginable in science fiction are now delivered directly into the consumer's pocket. This new era has borne a global paradigm shift. We have become hooked on our machines. This series is a look into the submissive personality - one surrendered to machines. It is a glimpse at the presence, or lack thereof, that occupies the human mind. This project will examine the subconscious of a fully evolved, present-day human. Have we been numbed by machines? Are we the makers or the made? "Machines" explores the serenity and beauty of our collective vulnerability. The surreal and disquieting acceptance humans have so readily embraced. As a fashion photographer, I consider women my medium. The quiet gentleness of classical femininity mirrors many of the passive traits we've come to accept under the dominance of technology, and it's through the female body and its gestures that I express these concepts.  

The production of "Machines" will start this summer. Cushioned by weeks of pre and post production. "Machines" premier exhibition will take place this fall at "The Royal" in Brooklyn, New York.

www.rsoaa.com

 

The funds raised in this campaign will go towards the following: 

- State of the art Camera & Equipment rentals

$2,000 +

- Studio/location rentals

$2,000+

- Talent & production crew costs

$4,000+

- Props, set, & costume

$3,000 +

- Mural sized prints & finishings for gallery exhibition  

$7,000 +

 

Below: Image from most recent project "Creatures" 

Image from recent photo series "Creatures" 2012

story:
The Short Version

I am going on a trip to Europe jan25 to june23, 22 weeks. It will be a work, study, and play trip, involving permaculture, blacksmithing, and product concept and design.


This indiegogo project is to help cover the costs of the last item, which involves observing, experiencing  photographing, cataloging, sketching, and developing designs based on my new experiences on this trip. I will need to cover not only the cost of printing the book, but the smaller backer incentives, but also part of the travel costs and the time it will take to organize this all! I also hope to develop some items and pieces based on this design research process!

The Long version...

What's My Deal?

I have a mission. I will be flying to London to start what will be a 22 week adventure of a lifetime across western europe, the British isles, and wherever else I end up (already have plans to fly to Kiev Ukraine!). As a creative type(artist and writer), this is a unique chance to obtain an expansive catalog of memories and experiences to be used as fodder for whatever I want to create. I will be exposed to an entirely new world of people, places, things, and ideas to bring back with me. New sights, sounds, and ideas to further my creative processes. I want to take photos, notes, and even samples of local culture, design, shape, and style to bring back and use in my own work. Even more so, I want to expand my experience and tap into even deeper reserves of ideas by triggering new thoughts and feelings. What a tall order!

This is where I need your help. I've managed to save most of what I need to cover my trip, but have fallen a bit short. I'll be making ends meet one way or the other (short order cook in germany? Physical labor in Italy?), but I had an interesting idea. As an artist and writer, the potential for this trip to inform both areas of focus, I'd like to be able to spend a bit of extra time doing just that. So the less I am chasing sheep across Spain to earn money, the more time I can spend collecting inspiration!


The Impact

Ideally I will have a very rich and complex experience filled with epiphanies and revelations that will inform and enrich my life from here on out.


As for the project. I feel that sometimes "the artist" is mystified into a complex system of creation that the "non creatives" don't get. First, there is no such thing as a "non creative" and second, it's not that mystical. We (creative folk) just express what we see, do, hear, and experience in whatever medium suits. In this case, I feel like harvesting ideas and concepts and inspiration, and formulating it into a book, allows for people to see not only my travel perspectives as an individual, but also as an artist. See how my brain gears work. What was I looking at when I visited the white cliffs, or the Paris streets. With the inspiration flow charts and photos, along with stories, journal entries, and personal thoughts, readers will be able to not only experience my trip second hand, which is an interesting thing unto itself, but also get an idea for what I am focusing on as I explore.

What's in the Book?

The general gist is this: I would like to compose a collection of short stories, sketches, design processes, photos, travel notes, and whatever else seems to fit from the trip. While much writing will occur during the trip, I would like to reserve the time for experiences and information gathering, and write the bulk of the work when I get home based on notes. 

Since When are You a Writer?

They say that decent writing is about relaying concepts to others that they don't already have, and that excellent writing conveys ideas and emotions in a way that captures your readers even if they already know what you're talking about. In past classes we talked about how a writer will write from his or her hometown perspective whether they want to or not, and as soon as we try to write a story about somewhere that we have no experience, it becomes obvious to yourself and the reader. If you're french, you will write best about french things. American's know America. it takes a really fantastic writer to capture the honest local vibe of a place they have never been, and they may still not be able to fool the locals.

Well, from the academic side, I've studied linguistics a bit, a few foreign languages, taken writing classes both analytical and creative. I love words. I find written communication to be extremely powerful because you aren't fed so many other layers of communication. There is no body language, facial expressions, audible tone or volume. A person can take a week writing a few sentences or lay waste to a few pages in a matter of minutes. Because of this, what ends up on the page is interpreted more or less for what it presents to the reader. There is no room for error, the message must be tuned as accurately as possible to what you want to convey. 

From a creative perspective, this means that the more fodder you have in your brain to pick through when writing, the better.

Ok, So What About the Art Stuff?

Artists are the great communicators of our world (Even more historically so then writers!). We catalog ideas, emotions, and concepts present in our lives into tangible goods and items that can often survive many years, even centuries. How cool! We draw from our surroundings, lives, locations, upbringing, and genetic memory to create new(I hope) and interesting(I pray) pieces for others to enjoy. Again, as with writing, these things don't come cheap. You must draw on that which you have experienced to create new designs. The more you see, do, learn, and are, the more expansive and informed your artwork can be. Maybe it's something extremely simple like a basic shape or form. Maybe you spend months working on one piece with intricacies that only you know. The potential is nearly endless!

Money Talks...

The catch is, a trip like this is not cheap. I will be traveling for fun, but also for work. I have a few eco-design and permaculture stops planned, and even a few blacksmith/jeweler friends I am going to visit and help out for a few days to learn some new stuff. But more relevant still, I would like to make this process of intellectual harvesting a significant part of my trip by taking notes and photos and writing as I go. Once I get back, I would love to compose everything into a book of some sort and have a limited printing! This way, when I am famous, you lucky investors will have a Douglas Cedric original book ;-)

Unfortunately, this is very abstract. I don't like tying myself down with rules and stipulations for a project like this, but I must offer something that appeals to investors. As such, I have composed a list of wide-ranging options for your backing my project, and I hope that you will find something interesting for you and tell your friends!

Half of the money will go towards travel supplies and food while I am out there, as well as transportation. The other half will go towards the backer items!

Dude... that's a long time...

Don't I know it!
Once upon a time I did a wilderness immersion and survival training course through a company in Portland, OR. We spend 3-4 days a week, every week, for 8 months out in the woods. Anywhere from the oregon coast, to central oregon, the gorge, high elevation forests and watersheds, and many Willamette valley locations. With travel included, I spent less time per capita at home during that 8 months then I did away. I lived out of my backpack and my car for most of it, couch hoping some weekends and only being home for an hour or two! And you know what? I LOVED it.
Never have I felt as free of stress and troubles. Never have I felt so healthy and grounded! Ironic, aye? Turns out I love my studio space, and I love having a home to go to, but I am a traveler at heart. Give me a backpack and some gear and some cheese, and I am happy pretty much anywhere.

With that said, yeah, this is a long trip! It will be exhausting at times, and I am sure there will be tricky parts, but all in all I expect this to not only be an amazing opportunity to improve my creative works in both art and writing, but also to take myself to the next level. Take this challenge and evolve.

Where did you get this crazy idea?

I have been plotting this trip since I was in highschool! But if I gave you a quick list of everything I've been up to in he last 8 years you'd see why it took me so long to set it up! Most recently though, trip planning, research, and networking begain about a year ago. So far I have about 6 weeks worth of housing. Thanks to my participation in mounted archery competition and demonstrations, I will be visiting some fellow horse-people on my travels. Thanks to my blacksmithing community involvement, I will be visiting many of them as well, including going to the 2012 Blacksmith's Festival in Ukraine! And lastly, I have been networking on couchsurfing.com to try and find housing for as much of my trip as possible. Any days I don't have friends to stay with I will be doing the hostel-dance and looking for cheap beds!

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends! Post on facebook, twitter, G+, myspace(people still use that?!), tell your friends and family, and spread the word! The more people that hear of it, the better chance I have!

story:
About Paje

     Paje is an artist, and generally a very thrifty one at that! She makes art in whatever medium she can afford, using what she can find. This has come to include, but is not limited to, sketching, painting, sculpting, sewing, songwriting, sewing, papercraft, calligraphy, bead mosaics, and jewelry making (under the tutaledge of her mother).

     Recently, though, Paje has switched jobs, and while she loves the one she is currently working, it has come to her attention that it is not enough to pay the bills! So she has decided that to make enough money on the side to keep herself afloat and keep doing what she loves, she must tap into what she does best- ART, and hope that it can make ends meet!

     That's where you come in dear friends! She needs a few things to get started, and the help is greatly appreciated, because without this help she cannot even begin!

Where your hard earned money is going!

     Paje doesn't need too much, in fact, with five hundred dollars she thinks could probably start a small face painting business, or heck, even become a party clown who does balloon animals and juggling in addition to face painting, but every cent will find it's way into the grand face painting scheme.

     To begin she'll need paints. They will ideally be something like this http://www.snazaroo.com/catalogue/catalogue.aspx?id=12578

     Then probably brushes and sponges. Those will generally cost about 25 dollars all together.

      She'll need two chairs, one for herself and one for the person getting their face painted. She estimates those will be around forty dollars together.

     Next is a little table, in which to put said paint and brushes on. She would ideally have this one http://www.amazon.com/Table-Bag-W2716-Portable-Carrying/dp/B001V7B2OY/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1380873454&sr=8-3&keywords=travel+table as it looks easily portable!

     Next come a few small things, like a spray bottle, a water dish, and a little pail for tips. She doubts these will come to more then twenty dollars.

     And lastly among the essentials she'd like a little cart, like adorable grannies use to carry their groceries up hills. Paje has no car, so she will often be carting all of these beautiful things on a bus or BART with her, and will need some sort of support (she is with child and that's very exciting, but also limits how much she can carry) She has this one in mind, http://www.amazon.com/heavy-duty-folding-matching--Basket--Jumbo/dp/B002C7U6UI/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&qid=1380873961&sr=8-5&keywords=rolling+cart !

     "But wait," you may be saying, "all of that only comes up to about 240!" Yes, and she would still try and do this with fifty. So what happens if she makes it all the way to the grand five hundred dollars? Basically she'd like to add a few colors of paint to the starter set of colors. She'd like to be able to take pictures of her work, then print and laminate those pictures to make a sign, so people have an idea of what she can do when the walk up. She'd also like to add a few fun things to her repertoire, like the aforementioned balloon animals and juggling, but she has a little more than zero training in either of those. She may even sew up a funny costume to wear while she does these things, but mostly it's the extra colors. She'd like to be able to pull out any color she needed when the time called for it. OOH and maybe some glitter!

     But she isn't just asking for something for nothing, NO! She'd like to give you tokens of affection for helping her achieve her small colorful dreams! Things like cartoony doodles, old timey line sketches, personally written songs about a subject of your choice, possibly on ukulele, or tiny sculptures of like gnomes, or flamingos, or something. Maybe even a hat!

     You can help a Paje today!

Other Ways You Can Help

     If you cannot contribute, or even if you feel like this is not the project you want to get behind, I understand! I have been beyond broke sometimes when people I know have asked for help, even when I have wanted dearly to donate. It's okay! If you can please boost the signal. 

     It takes a lot for a person like me to swallow my pride and tell people I need help, even for something that seems as small and trivial as this. This isn't small or trivial to me, it's huge, and I'm grateful that I've surrounded myself with the sorts of people that I can bring this to. Thank you dearly- even for just reading this!
story_txt:
About Paje
     Paje is an artist, and generally a very thrifty one at that! She makes art in whatever medium she can afford, using what she can find. This has come to include, but is not limited to, sketching, painting, sculpting, sewing, songwriting, sewing, papercraft, calligraphy, bead mosaics, and jewelry making (under the tutaledge of her mother).
     Recently, though, Paje has switched jobs, and while she loves the one she is currently working, it has come to her attention that it is not enough to pay the bills! So she has decided that to make enough money on the side to keep herself afloat and keep doing what she loves, she must tap into what she does best- ART, and hope that it can make ends meet!
     That's where you come in dear friends! She needs a few things to get started, and the help is greatly appreciated, because without this help she cannot even begin!


Where your hard earned money is going!
     Paje doesn't need too much, in fact, with five hundred dollars she thinks could probably start a small face painting business, or heck, even become a party clown who does balloon animals and juggling in addition to face painting, but every cent will find it's way into the grand face painting scheme.

This isn't small or trivial to me, it's huge, and I'm grateful that I've surrounded myself with the sorts of people that I can bring this to. Thank you dearly- even for just reading this!

story:
About the Artist

For many years, I've "mucked about" as an artist.

I took countless art classes in High School and early on in college, but I never thought that art could be my passion. I was told so often, by people I respected and loved, that I needed to find a job that would pay my bills. I took their advice and I went to business school for a B.B.A with a minor in Entrepreneurship.

During that process I went back and forth with myself on whether it was the right path for me. (Turns out, it was!) I continued to draw in my spare time, but I was focused on learning everything I could about having my own business.

When I was 21, I was back living with my parents after a really bad breakup. I was unemployed, freshly home from living out of state, with a healthy dose of humility gained from a failed attempt at moving across country. While sitting in the basement trying to figure out how to pay my student loans, I stumbled upon Etsy.com. That summer I jumped in full tilt making cutesy little things that I thought I could sell to housewives with young children. (Turns out, I couldn't.)

I found a job (finally) but I continued in the same young child vein for about a year and a half. I tried a lot of different handicrafts during that time, though. Nothing was sacred. I rediscovered myself as an artist; mod podge, scrapbooking, water color, quilting, perler beads...

Finally, one night I was sitting at my sketchbook when my best friend, Frances, called me. She had gotten her own work into an art show, and was seeing if I had put any work into it.  I figured, "Hey! Nothing else has worked!" and I submitted my illustrations into the show. I noticed that the group was offering merchandise tables for a small fee as well, and I thought, "Why the hell not?!" so I bought a table, too.

Oh... Did I mention that I didn't have ANY merchandise ready, exactly 0 paintings made to display in the show, no way to display anything on my table, and no understanding of how to get ready?

I had a month to get ready. 1 month. I took some time off of work and began planning fervently. I knew that in order to be a success to myself I would need to look professional and like I've done a show before. So, I took to the internet, pouring over guides, walkthroughs, photos, Vlogs, blogs, and everything else I could find. And I made it happen!

By the end of the show I looked to my fiancee, tears streaming down my face, and said, "This is what I want to do for the rest of my life!" I knew that I had finally found my passion, and now I want to share that passion with the world.

 

What is this?!

This campaign is to help me to get to Youmacon 2013, which is an anime convention in downtown Detroit, MI during late October. This is the biggest convention in Michigan and one of the biggest in the country. Artist Alley this year is about $150/table (plus however many helpers I'm going to need, which is only 1 person.)

This is going to be my first major convention, but I've done a couple of small ones in the past; mainly local art shows or putting paintings in galleries and such.  There is also a local anime/game convention coming up that I'm doing with a high school.  Pretty much every chance that's being put in front of me, I'm jumping on.

Youmacon would be a giant leap forward for me and my dreams of doing art shows and conventions forever; I'm sure my fiancee is going to be thrilled with that.  The idea of seeing happy people, dressed as eccentric characters coming by my booth and talking makes my heart jump every time I think it. 

 

What is your hard-earned cash going to?

For the main goal I will need:

  • $300 for the booth and badges
  • $300 for the hotel for the weekend and gas to Detroit from Ann Arbor
  • $150 for the cost of prints and packaging
  • The rest is going to be eaten by fees from indiegogo and paypal. :(

 

If I am lucky enough to raise MORE than the asking $750 I will be getting these things:

  • Button maker
  • Getting calendars printed
  • A nice display rack
  • T-shirts printed
  • Marker refills to make more art with (my markers are refillable)
  • New business cards printed
  • A new color Laser printer

 

If I'm not able to meet the entire goal I will use the funds to try to get into a smaller convention. No matter what, I want to get into a show :)

 

How can you help?

Tweet about this, spread the word, tell your friends, share this on Facebook, comment on my youtube channel, tell the press. If you can't donate money, please share me on Facebook, twiiter, instagram, pinterest and wherever else you can find someone to listen!

story:
WHAT IS SWAN DAY?

"SWAN Day/Support Women Artists Now Day is a new international holiday that celebrates women artists.  It is an annual event taking place on the last Saturday of March (Women’s History Month) and the surrounding weeks.

By focusing attention on the work of women artists, SWAN Day helps people imagine what the world might be like if women’s art and perspectives were fully integrated into all of our lives.

People celebrate this new holiday by participating in SWAN Day events and by making donations to their favorite women artists. The long term goal of SWAN Day is to inspire communities around the world to find new ways to recognize and support women artists as a basic element of civic planning." WomanArts.org

 

WHAT I NEED

Every donation, no matter how small, will earn my heartfelt gratitude. 

Being an artist is a wonderful and personally rewarding way to make a living, "if you can afford it".

In these economical time this is the reality I face, "Can I afford to contiune to be a "full-time" artist?" and just as important, "Can I mentally and emotional afford not to?"

When I go through challenging finacial periods and I question what I should do I always find myself going back to the horses, back to the "Words of Wisdom," back to the experience of creativing.

  

For the past 14 years I have depended on Horse Expos and to make a living. For the past 3 years it has been a struggle as "Made in China" and other imported/mass produced products fill the booths making it hard for artists like myself to compete. 

The reality is that the average cost of doing a week-end show, (10x10 booth fee, gas, food and lodging) for me is about $1,500.00. In these economical times it is getting harder and harder to make any kind of profit let alone pay your bills and rent.

I known my work is important, I know I should continue but I need to make changes. I have been spending a great deal of time in front of the computer up-dating my website, shopping cart, learning photoshop, supervising my intern, leanring social media, reserching new ways to market my art and home decor collections, etc. etc. All the necessary things one has to do to run a busineess. The problem is my creativeity is my business. 

I felt that SWAN DAY "Supporting Women Artist Now" was the perfect venue to ask for help.

Funds raised during this celebration (March & April) will go to off-set the costs for my April Shows, Equine Affaire/Ohio and Midwest Horse Fair/WI so I can have extra money to hire professionals to help me market my art and home decor line properly. 

 

THE IMPACT MY WORK HAS HAD ON OTHERS

"Just a quick note to let you know how impressed we were with your beautiful calendar. We want to wish you much success in furthering this lovely art. Your messages are heart felt and people need to know (and taken in) that we are all children of One God." -Lisa, AZ   

 "I can't tell you how much pleasure your delightful little horses bring me. They bring comfort, joy, peace and an element of beautiful fantasy to my world. They surround me everywhere in my living/dining room area where I spend  great part of my time. Thank you for being artistic. I'm so glad I met you. As soon as I saw the horses in your booth I knew I had to have them in my world. Jackie (CA)   

 "Just wanted to tell you how much I love the 2 horses and calendars I bought from you. My sister absolutely loved the Gone-But-Not-Forgotten pony and calendar in memory of our Dad, she & my whole family consider the pony and calendar as family treasures." -Wanda (ND) 

"This horse is absolutely incredible. He exceeds all my hopes and dream for him. Thank you so much for the beautiful and skilled work, for your careful selection of meaningful materials, colors and images, and for the love you poured into him".The detail on Niizhota is exquisite and he truly is a tribute to Ted and his heritage. Morgan (Canada)  NIIZHOTAY (Ojibway)-“TWO HEARTS” Hand-made custom horse created to honor husband's Ojibway Native American heritage.

THE ARTIST

 
Ask any family member or one of her oldest friends, the deep currents of Denise Banda's life are her love of horses, mountains and wide-open spaces. She also has a sustained interest in Native American culture, their symbolism and traditions. She became an artist gradually, almost unintentionally, after exploring photography and the film industry. Eventually, those symbiotic currents carried her away to the mountains and to her life as an artist.

 

In the early stages of my work I gathered driftwood, feathers, leather and stones to assemble my primitive art, to sell at shows and to friends. A mentor who understood my passion for horses, challenged me to try sculpting them from clay. As my work in this new medium evolved I employed increasingly creative combinations of firing and glazing methods. Now gemstones and beadwork embellish each horse, and my finished pieces express the power and energy of a protective fetish. 

 

 Ever since these "spirit horses" have entered my life, I have been crisscrossing the vast expanse of the US traveling from one show to the next. My product line has expanded to include popular home d'cor and clothing items. A loyal group of collectors seek out my booth, mingling with those who are first discovering the unique vibrancy of myart. 

 

Without knowing where it would lead, I followed my inner guide, devoting myself to my art. Now at a turning point, after 13 years on the road it's time to shift away from the draining life of a solo traveling artist. Approaching the wise elder cycle, I need your helping hand to take Mountain Feather Originals to the next level.

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Please share my SWAN DAY campaign with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn. Every clicks helps this campaign draw more attention and move it up in ranking. 


TEAM

Denise Banda-artist/owner/designer

 www.mountainfeatheroriginals.com

Contact

Deanna Stropes-copywriter, copy editor

Andrea Featherston-Rossi-Roanoke Design & Marketing 

Patrick S. Devine-Graphic Design Intern WCTC

WomenArts.org


SPONSOR

 STARTUP AMERICA-White House initiative to support American entrepreneurship; selected Mountain Feather Originals for its pilot program & recommended IndieGoGo as a potential funding resource

story:
Discovery Week (DYP)

Discovery Week is scheduled for February 19-22. During Discovery Week, we set aside the ordinary school week and provide students with hands-on, student-centered learning opportunities. Students will have the chance to choose from 60+ classes. We need your help to make it happen.

Here are some of the sixty classes planned:

origami • firearms and hunting • Japanese cooking • making deer calls • cribbage • bead making • job shadowing • juggling • Dancing with the Stars• music residency • theater games • herbal medicine • organic jewelry making • outdoor survival • cooking 101 • trebuchet making • digital photography • paint.net • traditional fishing • drumming • instrument making • skateboard decks • glass mosaics • mural design • Coast Guard boot camp • digital storytelling • documentary film making • cedar bark work • Ravenstail weaving • seal oil rendering • babysitting 101 • readers’ theater • Pilates • archery • sea kayaking • Filipino cooking • steam punk costuming • first aid • soap making • water polo • knitting • vocal • breakdancing • freshwater fishing • Russian cooking

What DYP Needs

Hands-on learning requires materials: tools, utensils, paper, wood, clay, paint, camera cards, groceries, wax, and much more. We also use funds to pay for rental fees.

Wild Enthusiasm

The aim of the project is to help students build assets for a healthy and happy life. This program complements Blatchley’s anti-bullying and “positive behavioral supports” programs in building students’ assets for success. 99% of students surveyed about DYP 2011 expressed strong approval or WILD ENTHUSIASM for DYP.

Ways to Help

Do you have a skill you would like to share? DYP needs instructors and class aides during Discovery Week. Please email Kari Sagel at sagelk@sitkaschools.org or call 907-752-7323 for more information. Please help us spread the word about our indiegogo campaign. Post us on Facebook.
