Discovery Week is scheduled for February 19-22. During Discovery Week, we set aside the ordinary school week and provide students with hands-on, student-centered learning opportunities. Students will have the chance to choose from 60+ classes. We need your help to make it happen.
Here are some of the sixty classes planned:
origami • firearms and hunting • Japanese cooking • making deer calls • cribbage • bead making • job shadowing • juggling • Dancing with the Stars• music residency • theater games • herbal medicine • organic jewelry making • outdoor survival • cooking 101 • trebuchet making • digital photography • paint.net • traditional fishing • drumming • instrument making • skateboard decks • glass mosaics • mural design • Coast Guard boot camp • digital storytelling • documentary film making • cedar bark work • Ravenstail weaving • seal oil rendering • babysitting 101 • readers’ theater • Pilates • archery • sea kayaking • Filipino cooking • steam punk costuming • first aid • soap making • water polo • knitting • vocal • breakdancing • freshwater fishing • Russian cooking

What DYP Needs
Hands-on learning requires materials: tools, utensils, paper, wood, clay, paint, camera cards, groceries, wax, and much more. We also use funds to pay for rental fees.
Wild Enthusiasm

The aim of the project is to help students build assets for a healthy and happy life. This program complements Blatchley’s anti-bullying and “positive behavioral supports” programs in building students’ assets for success. 99% of students surveyed about DYP 2011 expressed strong approval or WILD ENTHUSIASM for DYP.

Ways to Help
Do you have a skill you would like to share? DYP needs instructors and class aides during Discovery Week. Please email Kari Sagel at sagelk@sitkaschools.org or call 907-752-7323 for more information. Please help us spread the word about our indiegogo campaign. Post us on Facebook.

story:
Mama Lava serves as an artistic intervention by introducing a new template of spiritual activism. As our society approaches environmental, social and spiritual choice points, how are we to continue as a human race on this lovely planet earth we inhabit together?

Mama Lava is in the format of a play and musical combined with the energy of a sacred ceremony.  Featuring transformational story-telling, sound healing, turntablism, movement, fashion design, performance and installation art, Mama Lava is a mechanism for spiritual healing, during a time of great evolutionary shift that has been prophesied for millennia. The piece will debut June 7th and 8th at Kraine Theater in NYC, and will take the audience on a journey.

Mama Lava will introduce dimensions of being while touching on societal wounding and injustices from earthly realms such as; the worldwide disappearance of bee populations, copywriting and manipulation of seeds by large corporations, abuse, cultural trauma, racial injustice, the oppression of women and more. These timely and sensitive topics will be put into perspective by teachings about our psychological, spiritual and energetic development, the evolution of our species, the introduction of divine templates of the masculine and feminine, and the power of prayer and intention. 

The intention of the piece is to inspire others to be a part of a global shift towards unity and to foster healing. Through the intention and container of the performance, non-serving beliefs and energies will be released and transmuted, and a peaceful sustainable template for us, will be imbued into consciousness. Mama Lava will also spread awareness about personal transformation, breaking down the walls of what is taboo, while welcoming others to feel safe, accepted and at peace no matter what they have been through in life.

Mama Lava intends to create a new, harmonious sustainable paradigm for our world based on the infinite possibilities within us. Together we can be of service towards global awakening in this crucial time of change. This approach to "healing" is an integral part of a journey towards wholeness. This works on physical, energetic, spiritual, emotional, and mental level and will assist the audience in reaching a profound self-love and acceptance, from which anything is possible.

The performance ceremony is a creation of Lauren “DJ Chela” Harkrader, a DJ, songstress, activist, artist, and long-time healer in a variety of modalities including; Reiki, Brennan Healing Science, Sound Healing and is also a Reverend and doula. “Greek Chorus” members, Jazabel Jade, a celebrated burlesque performer and activist, and educator, choreographer and dancer Lorilee Chien join her.

We’re asking for your help to bring this project to life as your generous donations will help us secure the performance location and rehearsal spaces, and other logistics including set and costume design, promotional materials, travel and more. The perks for your contribution are in the form of sacred creations imbued with the healing intentions behind Mama Lava; the Mama Lava soundtrack, mandalas, jewelry, as well as healing sessions from Chela - either in person or long-distance.

Infinite thanks for your consideration in making this critical project possible. If you can’t contribute financially at this point, we hope you will see the performance June 7th and 8th. You can help us spread the word about Mama Lava via this page. Stay up to date on our creative process through our Facebook and twitter pages. 

We can create a new, harmonious sustainable paradigm for our world based on the infinite possibilities within us. Thanks again for your support, may you feel as blessed and smiled upon as you indeed are! Aho.

story:
Who

Hi! My name is kris, I make music and sound projects. I studied applied physics and my passion has always been sound and it s social function. I work as a professional sound engineer for broadcast, documentary films and adverts. I’m from Germany,  living regularly in Berlin, running a sound studio there.

What

The Sonic Landscape Interventions is a sound project I will run at the Chalk Hill Residency in California.

Sonic Landscape Interventions is an interactive and participatory sound scape project. The final
soundscape can be experienced on the Chalk Hill Residency and its surroundings via smartphone application with headphones. Walking through the landscape the
listener listens back (via GPS - tagging of the sounds) to fieldrecordings / performances / voices that were recorded in place. The “sound
walker” creates his on narration by choosing his/her way through the landscape. This soundscape can
be experienced to every time, also years later.
As a “miniature for mobiles” the final acoustical sculpture can be listened
back on the web page of the aporee Project and embedded on an extra project sound blog and the chalk hill residencies homepage.

 

I will record sound (fieldrecordings, ambient recordings) from the surroundings of the area, and will make interviews with people and artists from that region. 

It will be a participative project, where everyone can contribute something. There will be a series of in situ micro concerts in the countryside that will be recorded and put on the map. At the end I want to have a sound map on aporeemaps, which is something you can simplified imagine as google maps for sound, but it is more than that. and auditive map , with small histories of people, sounds from waterfalls and animals, barely anything that is audible and interesting.

I will design a Sonic Landscape Miniatures.

 


Later people can go for a walk with their smartphones in that area and enjoy the soundscape, like a radioplay you can literally walk through.

for that project i ll work together with the aporee maps and the Chalk Hill Residency, where i reside as an artist in residency.

I will make a strongly limited edition of individualized soundwalks. these can be purchased by donating more than 65$


To make this happen, I need financial support in order to pay a part of the plane ticket, purchase materials, rent a car for doing interviews and finance my living during the period of working. I will work for six weeks fulltime on that project, during that time i wont have another source of income. I’ve decided to ask for your help to reach my goal of $1200 for the production of the Sonic Landscape Interventions.

 

How

 

To complete my project, I need some backing in order to:

 

- finance a part of my flight from Berlin to San Francsisco. 

- purchase 2-3 smartphones I will leave at the Ranch and that are available for all visitors to experience the sonic landscape

- rent a car for 2 weeks for doing interviews, collecting storys and sounds that are not reachable by bike

- make the cd s and boxes for the supporters of the project

- print flyers and posters to promote the project

- rent some video gear for a "making of" film of the project, that will also being posted here. 

 

 

 

If you’d like to support the project, there are several ways you can help, that I hope will correspond to people’s budgets:

 

- a "supporters" credit w/ your name and website (if wanted) 

- the “sonic landscape” CD (with selfmade packaging)

- a unique box with a small found object and a personalized soundwalk made by myself on a cd especially made for you!

If I’m unable to reach my goal, the funds will still go towards the realisation of the project and you will still receive a cd or box! 

 

Why

 

I feel that with the Sonic Landscape - Project I will be able to contribute something to the world that is missing: a chance to hear how a place or region sounds, even when you are in another part of the world. 

we experience our world by seeing, reading and watching and I want to enhance and enlarge this "vision" by adding sound to it.

 Sound is a remarkable footprint of our ecosystem , that we should not miss to document and experience. It changes and is never the same. And theres a creative potential in exploring and transforming these sounds.  I want to do both of that. 

 

I hope you find this of interest and feel like helping out! If you have any questions please feel free to get in touch (emitter19 plus gmail)- and if you think of anyone who would be interested in the project please don’t hesitate on sharing this - thanks!

story:
I had been a comic book fan for many, many years before I discovered Scott McCloud. It was Scott McCloudâ€™s Understanding Comics that opened my mind to the vast potential of comics, but it was the oversized Destroy! that struck a chord with me. In Destroy!, McCloud presents the idea that Jack Kirby was so dynamic and so original that all comic creators dwell in his shadow. He further says that all comic artists have been trying to out "Kirby" Jack Kirbyâ€¦ that we all are trying to produce works that are more dynamic, more bombtastic, more KIRBY than Jack Kirby himself.

That haunted with me for years because I never had a desire to out â€œKirbyâ€ Jack Kirby. I wanted to blaze my own trail as small press comic creator. In the last 6 years, I have worked (and have received published credit) in every aspect of comic book creation. It is now Iâ€™m ready to embark on my own Jack Kirby journey. Iâ€™m ready for My Jack Kirby Project!

My Jack Kirby Project began with a 12"x 12" simple proof of concept painting that I called Kirby Krackle. I sat down with a canvas, brush and 3 colors of paint and just created Kirby's renown krackle. Later, it stuck me to I recreate the painting digitally and then I was struck with the idea of using Kirby krackle to recreate panels from Jack Kirby's Fourth World. And now here we are!

I went through Kirby's Fourth World epic from his first issue of Jimmy Olsen through the Hunger Dogs Graphic Novel and I chose 12 panels that resonated the power and design of Jack Kirby. Using those panels as inspiration, I created quick sketches that would serve as my guide as I recreated the panels with Kirby krackle.



digital sketches of the chosen Kirby panels


My goal with this project wasn't to do Lichtenstein type recreations, but rather to do my own pop art Kirby krackle homage to the King of Comics. On 11 January 2012, I completed the last of my 12 prints and now I come to IndieGogo to get those prints in your hands. I'm offering 2 types of prints

1) Limited Edition signed and numbered prints
Limited to 25 these prints will be full color full bleed and printed on heavy lux cotton stock.This is a 118lb, bright white, uncoated paper stock with a soft cotton finish. Sizes are 11" x 17" or 17" x 11". These will be signed and numbered on the back and once the edition is gone, they are gone and will never be reprinted. 
My original print Kirby Krackle is limited to 77 and is 11" x 11".

2) Mass market prints will be full color full bleed 100 lb cardstock coated on both sides with a smooth satin finish.

The completed print designs can be seen on this projects Gallery as well as...
On my facebook fan page
In my deviant Gallery

There is also a book. The book is 8.5" x 11" and will feature 48 pages dedicated to this project. Inside the book you will find the print designs as well as the digital sketches, Fourth World panels and commentary about why I chose each panel. A PDF of this book will be available to everyone who contributes at least $10 to this project. All copies of the book shipped to contributors of the IndieGogo will have a special cover limited to just the IndieGogo supporters. Anyone that purchases the book at a later date will have a different cover.


For shipping outside the US, add $5 for Canada and $10 for all other international destinations.

No number requests will be honored on the prints. They are first come first served. The lower numbered editions will be rewarded to the earliest contributors starting with #1.


I have completed all the print designs for this project. All that remains is for me to design the book and send everything to the printer. The book design will be complete before this campaign ends and I plan to have everything printed and shipped by the first weeks of May.


MY GOAL
The goal is a $3000. This will allow me to print the complete run of all the Limited Editions, print copies of the mass market editions, print copies of the book, and ship everything to all contributors. Since this is a flexible funding project, everyone that makes a contribution will receive their perk whether or not the total goal is reached.
                                                  
What happens if you exceed the goal?
Any amount above $3000 will go towards increasing the print runs for the mass market prints and the book. Any amount above $5000 and I will donate 10% of that amount to the Jack Kirby Museum.


SHIPPING
All items will be shipped bagged to protect against moisture and sandwiched between 2 cardboard sleeves to protect against bending. Orders within the continental US will be shipped via Parcel Post. You can add an additional $5, for Priority Mail shipping. All international orders will be shipped via US International Priority. All items will be shipped together.

NOTE: At your request, I will sign any of the unsigned items. There is no additional charge for this.

Thanks you for supporting My Kirby Project. Share this campaign with your friends on Facebook, your followers on Twitter, and all the Kirby and comic fans in your life.

story:
Our First Freak In Production!

 

Tattoos
Tea Parties
Absinthe Tastings
Trundle Visits
T-Shirts!
Just some of the things you will get if you donate to our odd little cause!

Our Story

High atop one of Swissvale's many mountains in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania sits the Trundle Manor art house, inhabited by one Mr Arm and Miss Velda Von Minx. As these artists have gained much notoriety for their collection of oddities and Victoriana, their self-proclaimed tourist trap has been featured in known magazines (Pittsburgh Magazine, Top 50 Things To Do In Pittsburgh, Lux Magazine), television programs (CBS News, IFC’s The Grid), and many online blogs and news websites (Boing Boing, Post-Gazette, Patch, Oh Honestly Erin, Odd Things I’ve Seen). There is trouble in paradise, though, as they have grown restless with their confines and must venture forth to spread their unusual wonder throughout Pennsylvania and the surrounding states.

 

It is our pleasure to announce and warn the world of the Trundle Manor Traveling Creepshow. Soon, every man, woman, and child will be welcomed into a realm of bizarre antiquities and eccentric exhibits – a vision not even the strongest draught of absinthe could produce!

 

The Creepshow is a long thought up and much thought out performance art piece being brought to life by the warped genius and artistry of Mr Arm, Velda, and the miscreants they call their friends. We will be constructing cabinets, designing showpieces and literally piecing together creatures for your twisted amusement. Unlike many modern sideshows and haunted attractions, the Trundle Manor Traveling Creepshow will be made of real creatures and unusual items plucked from the minds of the Trundle Manor crew. Tucked behind the flaps of a twelve-foot circus tent will be a world wrought with dark dreams and shining nightmares. With an old world charm of a gypsy / carnival styled surrounding, the Creepshow will present an atmosphere that has been lost to time, complete with actors providing an obscure experience stricken by none other.

 

Beginning this August, the Creepshow will be setting up camp at various charity events, conventions, trade shows, flea markets, and festivals starting in greater Pennsylvania and across the east coast.

 

The plan is to use Mr Arm’s 1952 Dodge “Creep Rod” truck to tow a gypsy styled mini trailer in classic caravan style to conventions, fairs, and flea markets.

 

For a donation at the tent flap, curious folk will experience the wonder of Trundle Manor firsthand. Expect things preserved in jars, taxidermied oddities, eccentric mechanizations, and live entertainment from the freaks that proudly call themselves Trundles! Mr Arm has a glut of talented individuals that are excited to be a part of the traveling show and have grabbed on to the tasks of preparing the exhibits, designing personas to compliment the live environmental experience, and doing unusual promotion.

 

Our Impact

In the short life of the “open to the public” Trundle Manor, we have seen the eyes of hundreds of people change and become childlike and filled with wonder simply by crossing our threshold. They have seen something that they could never dream would be in a normal neighborhood. We know that the traveling show will do the same, but for thousands more. It breaks our hearts to think that many more could be brought this inspiration if only we could afford to. If our Creepshow remains in the shadows of financially motivated obscurity, the timeless ideal of the traveling show that has been a part of the grand American imagination will be far the lesser. Without the push of the dime museum, the carnie sideshow, the “freak” tent, the standard way of life is set lax in its imagination and applied rabid to the throws of the personal video game and the little man in the box known as television. Our Creepshow will farther the imagination and broaden the tactile sense of what could be out there if you take the time to dream it up. Without individuals believing in the unusual and the back alley safe oddness of our type of show, we, at Trundle Manor, know that even the simplest of childhood dreams could be lost.

What We Need and What You Get

In order to fund our nefarious schemes, we need your help to raise the sum of $5,000 to get our Trundle Manor Traveling Creepshow on the road.

 

Your donations will be used for many different pieces of this unusual artistic endeavor, such as:

 

  • The twelve-foot circular canvas tent that will house the exhibits has already been invested in with an exception to the costly steel support system that will allow it to be placed on any hard surface like a convention floor or parking lot. This tent will also be painted to display in a ballyhoo styled way, to showcase some of the more unique pieces and to draw in the crowd, which will require painting materials.
  • The work of creating the creatures for this piece will be done completely by the owners of Trundle Manor and their Igors but the materials must be acquired ahead of time such as taxidermy supplies and preservation solutions.
  • Each creature and oddity will have a specially designed case that reflects its personality that may consist of gold leafed bones, wooden and glass stands, mechanically activated movements, and etched brass plaques and accents. Along with these cases, electronic sound devices will be used to extend the experience to the auditory senses.
  • To house and haul the entire showpiece a gypsy wagon-styled trailer will have to be built. This design will also further the mystique of the traveling show, as Mr Arm believes that every little piece should contribute to the whole of the performance. Priced out, the cost of an enclosed trailer would be more than the design proposed by the Manor. This design includes a safe, store bought trailer base which will be built up with wooden sides and roof and will be painted to match the show. All of this will need to be purchased.
  • On top of this all, environmental pieces will need to be gathered such as rugs for the floor, drapery, mirrors for the walls, and lighting. The lighting will require a generator that has been priced at somewhat over $1000 to accommodate our needs for lighting, display electronics, speaker systems for mood music, and fog machine to emphasize the environment as part of our stage.

The donation goal has been carefully designed to accommodate a fluctuation of prices for materials, and the Creepshow’s ability to slowly gather more environmental materials in our travels. While it would be our greatest wish to be able to assemble all of our needed materials in this one fell swoop and we ask for you, our benefactors, to give until you bleed, we understand that this world is harsh, and we may not reach our goal. If this is the case, our cause will not go to the wayside but would be the lesser and may not be possible for some time. Mr Arm has been doing his best to produce expendable income for this life-changing project, but this may cause the beloved tourist trap / art house, Trundle Manor to falter and a Pittsburgh attraction will be hard hit.

 

Some of Our Rewards

By helping us, we have set up a vast array of gifts and experiences marked by donation amount that you will not be able to get anywhere in the world but here. Everything from limited edition buttons to private absinthe parties hosted at Trundle Manor for you and your friends. These are items that you may never forget. Each level gets Trundle Manor Villain buttons and tickets to the traveling show we are working towards.
Additional donation levels get you some other cool Trundle memorabilia:

  • From $25 up we’ll present you with a specially made and signed Certificate of Appreciation and your name will be etched on a plaque mounted to our Gypsy Wagon. Also past this mark, Phat Mandee is giving away a download of our favorite song, Ride the Rotor!
  • Limited edition Trundle Manor T-shirts in your size that will only be available to this campaign.
  • We offer cute touristy Manor postcards to send to your friends bragging about Pittsburgh’s coolest tourist trap.
  • You will be welcomed with door-donation-free admission to our aforementioned Trundle Manor for you and friends, and tickets to our Halloween party.
  • At the $250 level local tattoo legend, Cyco Mike, has offered to donate a tattoo to each individual with the stones to pony up the dough. His tattoos alone have gone for more than the donation price so snag these up.
  • At the higher levels Mr Arm is offering a Trundle Manor starter kit, a velvet lined box with what you need to open your own tourist trap.
  • Our parties that have been offered will be in your honor with friends you chose complete with absinthe tastings and tea cakes, all in there respective places of course. Phat Mandee has offered to sing at all parties from $500 to $1000, which equals a private showing of her amazing talents for your crew. Show your friends you are as cultured you think you are. After our campaign you can schedule your event whenever you like!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We plead to you to help get our idea out there and to promote our unusual performance piece that we hope will add much wonder to our local humanity, and might allow people to know that there are other things out there in the world and that they can have a hand in these other things. We will have postings on our website, and we could use your help by writing about us on your blog, talking about us at your local coffee shops, share us on your facebook page, or simply whisper our name in your local back alley to every one eyed hobo with two dollars to his name who is willing to donate one of them to our cause.

 

Head to www.TrundleManor.com for more information on our company and its founders! If you are in the Pittsburgh area, feel free to call or text Mr Arm (412)-916-5544 to schedule a tour of Trundle Manor or to discuss donations. Tours are by appointment only, so please make sure to call before you visit.

 

Thank you for paying the slightest bit of attention to our unusual cause and we wish you a strange life even if you do not decide to donate. But keep in mind; we will be coming for you.
story_txt:
Our First Freak In Production!
 
TattoosTea PartiesAbsinthe TastingsTrundle VisitsT-Shirts!Just some of the things you will get if you donate to our odd little cause!Our StoryHigh atop one of Swissvale's many mountains in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania sits the Trundle Manor art house, inhabited by one Mr Arm and Miss Velda Von Minx. As these artists have gained much notoriety for their collection of oddities and Victoriana, their self-proclaimed tourist trap has been featured in known magazines (Pittsburgh Magazine, Top 50 Things To Do In Pittsburgh, Lux Magazine), television programs (CBS News, IFC’s The Grid), and many online blogs and news websites (Boing Boing, Post-Gazette, Patch, Oh Honestly Erin, Odd Things I’ve Seen). There is trouble in paradise, though, as they have grown restless with their confines and must venture forth to spread their unusual wonder throughout Pennsylvania and the surrounding states. It is our pleasure to announce and warn the world of the Trundle Manor Traveling Creepshow. Soon, every man, woman, and child will be welcomed into a realm of bizarre antiquities and eccentric exhibits – a vision not even the strongest draught of absinthe could produce! The Creepshow is a long thought up and much thought out performance art piece being brought to life by the warped genius and artistry of Mr Arm, Velda, and the miscreants they call their friends. We will be constructing cabinets, designing showpieces and literally piecing together creatures for your twisted amusement. Unlike many modern sideshows and haunted attractions, the Trundle Manor Traveling Creepshow will be made of real creatures and unusual items plucked from the minds of the Trundle Manor crew. Tucked behind the flaps of a twelve-foot circus tent will be a world wrought with dark dreams and shining nightmares. With an old world charm of a gypsy / carnival styled surrounding, the Creepshow will present an atmosphere that has been lost to time, complete with actors providing an obscure experience stricken by none other. Beginning this August, the Creepshow will be setting up camp at various charity events, conventions, trade shows, flea markets, and festivals starting in greater Pennsylvania and across the east coast. The plan is to use Mr Arm’s 1952 Dodge “Creep Rod” truck to tow a gypsy styled mini trailer in classic caravan style to conventions, fairs, and flea markets. For a donation at the tent flap, curious folk will experience the wonder of Trundle Manor firsthand. Expect things preserved in jars, taxidermied oddities, eccentric mechanizations, and live entertainment from the freaks that proudly call themselves Trundles! Mr Arm has a glut of talented individuals that are excited to be a part of the traveling show and have grabbed on to the tasks of preparing the exhibits, designing personas to compliment the live environmental experience, and doing unusual promotion. Our ImpactIn the short life of the “open to the public” Trundle Manor, we have seen the eyes of hundreds of people change and become childlike and filled with wonder simply by crossing our threshold. They have seen something that they could never dream would be in a normal neighborhood. We know that the traveling show will do the same, but for thousands more. It breaks our hearts to think that many more could be brought this inspiration if only we could afford to. If our Creepshow remains in the shadows of financially motivated obscurity, the timeless ideal of the traveling show that has been a part of the grand American imagination will be far the lesser. Without the push of the dime museum, the carnie sideshow, the “freak” tent, the standard way of life is set lax in its imagination and applied rabid to the throws of the personal video game and the little man in the box known as television. Our Creepshow will farther the imagination and broaden the tactile sense of what could be out there if you take the time to dream it up. Without individuals believing in the unusual and the back alley safe oddness of our type of show, we, at Trundle Manor, know that even the simplest of childhood dreams could be lost.What We Need and What You GetIn order to fund our nefarious schemes, we need your help to raise the sum of $5,000 to get our Trundle Manor Traveling Creepshow on the road. Your donations will be used for many different pieces of this unusual artistic endeavor, such as: 
The twelve-foot circular canvas tent that will house the exhibits has already been invested in with an exception to the costly steel support system that will allow it to be placed on any hard surface like a convention floor or parking lot. This tent will also be painted to display in a ballyhoo styled way, to showcase some of the more unique pieces and to draw in the crowd, which will require painting materials.
The work of creating the creatures for this piece will be done completely by the owners of Trundle Manor and their Igors but the materials must be acquired ahead of time such as taxidermy supplies and preservation solutions.
Each creature and oddity will have a specially designed case that reflects its personality that may consist of gold leafed bones, wooden and glass stands, mechanically activated movements, and etched brass plaques and accents. Along with these cases, electronic sound devices will be used to extend the experience to the auditory senses.
To house and haul the entire showpiece a gypsy wagon-styled trailer will have to be built. This design will also further the mystique of the traveling show, as Mr Arm believes that every little piece should contribute to the whole of the performance. Priced out, the cost of an enclosed trailer would be more than the design proposed by the Manor. This design includes a safe, store bought trailer base which will be built up with wooden sides and roof and will be painted to match the show. All of this will need to be purchased.
On top of this all, environmental pieces will need to be gathered such as rugs for the floor, drapery, mirrors for the walls, and lighting. The lighting will require a generator that has been priced at somewhat over $1000 to accommodate our needs for lighting, display electronics, speaker systems for mood music, and fog machine to emphasize the environment as part of our stage.
The donation goal has been carefully designed to accommodate a fluctuation of prices for materials, and the Creepshow’s ability to slowly gather more environmental materials in our travels. While it would be our greatest wish to be able to assemble all of our needed materials in this one fell swoop and we ask for you, our benefactors, to give until you bleed, we understand that this world is harsh, and we may not reach our goal. If this is the case, our cause will not go to the wayside but would be the lesser and may not be possible for some time. Mr Arm has been doing his best to produce expendable income for this life-changing project, but this may cause the beloved tourist trap / art house, Trundle Manor to falter and a Pittsburgh attraction will be hard hit. Some of Our RewardsBy helping us, we have set up a vast array of gifts and experiences marked by donation amount that you will not be able to get anywhere in the world but here. Everything from limited edition buttons to private absinthe parties hosted at Trundle Manor for you and your friends. These are items that you may never forget. Each level gets Trundle Manor Villain buttons and tickets to the traveling show we are working towards.Additional donation levels get you some other cool Trundle memorabilia:
From $25 up we’ll present you with a specially made and signed Certificate of Appreciation and your name will be etched on a plaque mounted to our Gypsy Wagon. Also past this mark, Phat Mandee is giving away a download of our favorite song, Ride the Rotor!
Limited edition Trundle Manor T-shirts in your size that will only be available to this campaign.
We offer cute touristy Manor postcards to send to your friends bragging about Pittsburgh’s coolest tourist trap.
You will be welcomed with door-donation-free admission to our aforementioned Trundle Manor for you and friends, and tickets to our Halloween party.
At the $250 level local tattoo legend, Cyco Mike, has offered to donate a tattoo to each individual with the stones to pony up the dough. His tattoos alone have gone for more than the donation price so snag these up.
At the higher levels Mr Arm is offering a Trundle Manor starter kit, a velvet lined box with what you need to open your own tourist trap.
Our parties that have been offered will be in your honor with friends you chose complete with absinthe tastings and tea cakes, all in there respective places of course. Phat Mandee has offered to sing at all parties from $500 to $1000, which equals a private showing of her amazing talents for your crew. Show your friends you are as cultured you think you are. After our campaign you can schedule your event whenever you like!
 Other Ways You Can HelpWe plead to you to help get our idea out there and to promote our unusual performance piece that we hope will add much wonder to our local humanity, and might allow people to know that there are other things out there in the world and that they can have a hand in these other things. story:
I started making art out of pinball game session i have video recorded a table from above and produced a one image of the whole game session.
since its hard to find good condition and the ability to do so in Israel i have produced only two tables. my fantasy is to do about 100 of the major pinball table
and to capture them and display them bring the pinball to fine art because it is art as its self.

I am a young artist and a gamer and i try to bring video games to the fine art scene its in our pop culture and i cant ignore at as an artist and as a gamer so why not making art outa of it.

I need at least 1800$ to buy a ticket to pinbal hall of fame museum at las vegas or Professional & Amateur Pinball Association in Pennsylvania i have the equipment i need. of course i need more then 1800$ i cant do it alone and i need motel money.

I know its sounds fishy and all las vegas and stuff but its real stuff i want to do it and i wanna start with a ticket to las vegas/Pennsylvania first i am in contact with pinball hall of fame and PAPA.org  (Professional & Amateur Pinball Association)  and i just need the money to make this happen

Note that even if all is executed prossessing the images are not easy making the video stills images and making the one image takes time i give my self one year of work until the full art show.

story:
About This Project:

Big Brothers Big Sisters of the Greater Virginia Peninsula wants to hold youth art workshops and commission a piece of art representative of the organization as a fund-raiser. Headquartered in Williamsburg, Va., Big Brothers Big Sisters helps young people achieve their highest potential during their formative years by providing one-on-one positive, caring mentoring relationships with an adult. A volunteer provides guidance and friendship to a child living in an "at-risk" environment or a child of a parent who is deployed or killed in action. We are an organization that believes and practices the idea that it takes a community to raise a child.

We are a non-profit and are experiencing cuts in our funding. To offset these cuts, we have come up with a unique fundraising idea and a way to bring unique cultural experiences to the youth we serve, enter our project: Raising Awareness Through Art! On Sept. 23, the artist we have commissioned to create art representative of our organization, Larry "Poncho" Brown, will hold a youth art workshop. On Sept. 24, we will present an unveiling ceremony of the original is currently creating.

We need your help to support the commissioning of the piece and to help fund the youth art workshops!

 (Below are four rough sketches submitted by Poncho as options for Big Brothers to consider as a final piece.)

 

What will Raising The Arts do for Big Brothers Big Sisters?

Raising The Arts will help us introduce youth in our coverage area to a nationally renowned artist - a successful African American artist who makes his living with his art. Raising The Arts will allow students to have a hands-on art workshop with this nationally renowned artist. The youth we serve will be able to interact with Brown in a small intimate setting and let their imaginations and creativity take over. Raising The Arts also will allow Big Brothers Big Sisters to fund raise in a creative way and to try and recoup lost funding streams.

About The Artist

Over the past two decades, nationally renowned artist Larry "Poncho" Brown has dedicated his career to creating more than 65 creations for various organizations all over the country. His powerful portfolio of images was commissioned by non-profit organizations for event promotions or fundraising. We are truly honored to have him create an image for Big Brothers Big Sisters. See some other images Poncho has created for other organizations: https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.221443634620872.44691.131176456980924&type=1&l=f0d59db453 

Other Ways You Can Assist Big Brothers Big Sisters

Pass the word, buy a print for yourself, or buy a print for a friend. Simply stated... give the gift of art.

story:
Creating original imagery is my ideal passion. Isolated within my images that prompt imaginations are relative to life’s everyday awareness and experiences.

 

Hello, I am Richard Mann. As a numerous award winning Fine Art student since 1960 my formal education includes an AA, BFA and MA. All degrees are majored in Fine Art Photography. Creating inspiring Art for the past 53 years has always been my main desire in life. This funding campaign will allow me to upgrade to an adequate computer and camera that meets the important needs of developing high quality conceptual and documentary contemporary imagery. Acquiring the funds to obtain this equipment will contribute immensely toward reaching a level of artistic expertise.


The budget for a professional Canon EOS 5D Mark 111 camera cost around $4,000 which will be purchased from an old friend who owns Samy’s Camera in Los Angeles, wereas the Mac Book Pro 17" computer with functional programs and insurance will cost around $3,000 which can be obtained from my former graphics arts professor and associate. If the entire fundraising goal is not met, the funds will be kept in a restricted closed bank account until enough funds are obtained to raise the appropriate amount. 


Any contributions received whether they are slight or generous will be gratefully valuable which carries with it inspirational appreciation for my continuing to create art. The perks designated as gifts to contributors in the form of autographed reproductions etc. are distinctively chosen from my most popular images in my archives and well liked amongst collectors locally and aboard. 


Acquiring financial aid had gratefully contributed to my advanced education in the past, however these funds will contribute to continuing to expose my work to the world now and in the future. Even if contributions are not possible at this time, the acknowledgement of my work and this campaign is invaluable to my career in Fine Art. Please assist in getting the word out by forwarding this campaign on to others like yourself. 


Thank you,

Richard Mann

story:
Support New Observations magazine.


Issue 130, "On the Addressee".

Guest edited by Pedro A.H. Paixão. With special contributions by Giorgio Agamben, Matilde Campilho, Emanuele Coccia, Alexandre Conefrey, Bernardo Simões Correia, Emanuela De Cecco, Alessandro Di Pietro, Joana Escoval, Donna Ferrato, Toni Hildebrandt, Jean-Luc Nancy, Alexandre Nodari, Yasmil Raymond, Isabella Rodriguez, Fabián Ludueña Romandini, Jorge Leandro Rosa, Veronica Stigger. And also with work by Bas Jan Ader, Paulo Brighenti, Berta Ehrlich, Nan Goldin, Jean-Luc Moulène, Rui Moreira, Bruce Nauman, António Poppe, Cindy Sherman and André Vallias.


"Issue 130, "On the Addressee," considers a secret and urgent call that artists, poets and thinkers inscribe in their most intimate and demanding works: a call addressed to unknowable or posthumous addressees. It departs from an homonym essay written in 1913 by the poet Osip Mandelstam, in which he asked, “To whom does the poet speak?,” while considering a call another Russian poet addressed in 1828 to a posthumous reader. Centuries later we are celebrating that precarious bond shared between friends, artists and/or writers from different generations or across centuries, to expose what is sharable today and bring to life the crucial aspects of such experience. We are also paying tribute to our 1990 edition, issue 75, guest edited by the Italian publisher Ginevra Bompiani, titled "The Mood of Our Time."  We are considering in that idea of "mood" whether it has a temporary or lasting effect on ourselves and on present time: what is partaken in the possibility of sharing such lasting effects. We are asking for what is left at the core of our intimacy, that is owned by no one, and can be transmitted in a "sharing" without presuppositions or sovereign figures. Listening to earlier calls left by thinkers like Giorgio Agamben or Jean-Luc Nancy, in her volume, we are seeking to read what a "call" and an "addressee" are in our experiences in art today. Because as one philosopher said, "our coming was expected on Earth" – recalling humanities relationship with it as well as relations between, parent and child, teacher and student, and the unknowable or posthumous friend."

[Image: Issue 130 Cover, featuring Pedro A.H. Paxaio's red pencil drawing titled "P.P., 2014, from Imagines maiorum"]

Short Summary

New Observations  is a non-profit contemporary arts journal that is written, edited and published by the arts community in an expanded process. Each issue has a guest editor and a pertinent topic. The journal was founded in the early 1980's, covering New York's provocative art scenes at the time, expanding its horizons nation wide and internationally. Though the publication paused for 12 years, it happily relaunched with issue 129 in 2013.  Issue 130 is the second of the new series.
     With this campaign we are searching for support to finance futures issues as well as general operating expenses.
     Your support funds will allow us to print in a better quality environment and with the best materials with the most technologically advanced resouces. Offering a digital version is in development to reach an expanded audience through new media. Offering the public quality issues of New Observations, and being a conduit to present the visions of artists for a better future for our planet, is the mission of the journal, whose successful outcome depends on your help and support.

(The four sections below expose in depth how, and the reasons why, you can help us publish our extraordinary new issue):

1. What We Need & What You Get

  • The entire process of making an issue demands a minimum of $8,000.
  • You will get an impressive volume (#130) containing new contributions by some of the most important thinkers and artists of our times, including a challenging group of emergent philosophers and artists opening new horizons for our experience in the problematic and uncertain time in which we are living.
  • We are now gathering funds to support forward activity. Your support will not only give us breathing room, but also will make you part of this fabulous venture. Also, depending on the kind of support, you can be mentioned in the masthead as a "Supporter," "Friend," or "Patron".

2. The Impact

  • According to our founder: “Every group of friends is unknowingly representing a complex universe of thought and that it is sufficient to have its members put on the page something, anything, for a whole world to be revealed.” We intend to maintain this maxim, by exploring in the pages of each issue, these complex universes of thought for thinking and living art and culture today.
  • In particular, our newest issue hosts a crucial topic, "on the addressee," developed by the artist, thinker, and editor Pedro A.H. Paixão, who's complex persona asks: for whom does the poet and artist produce a poem or a work of art? But also, to whom does the philosopher write today? What is at stake in the calls that demand them to make work or share their thoughts, outside their professional roles?
  • We believe that you can engage with great commitment in being part of this genuine and generous enterprise, and that with every "new observation," every new emerging thought, every new sensible field, we propose, a new horizon line will be crossed together.

3. Risks & Challenges

  • To publish a non-profit publication means to live in a risky dimension and in a horizon of uncertainties. It means publishing without a precise date. That's why; above all, we are maintaining an annual issue. Rather than publishing on tight time schedules that produces insufficient results, we prefer to offer you the strongest outcome, by allowing each publication the conditions it needs to evolve to maturity.
  • Seeking the highest standards, we prefer to work under challenging conditions while engaging the most provocative artists and thinkers living today. This means a long maturation and dialogue with each guest editor, the authors and in understanding with transparency the topic we are working with.
  • Every new issue is a new field where we try to bring to your fore a pertinent and challenging aspect of contemporaneity, be it something forgotten or still missing, something hidden or too exposed, needing a new perspective to gain its proper dimension or value. We are measuring distances, searching new and old ways and modes of living, sources and new horizons that are keys to live well on our planet.

4. Other Ways You Can Help

  • We rely on you to share our campaign with your friends, followers, colleagues and those who would find your support of New Observations magazine of mutual interest.
  • Using the Indiegogo share tools helps you reach out to all your contacts, by word of mouth, or by word of web on networks like Facebook, Linkedin, Twitter, Email and in forums and chats. Please spread the news about what we are doing, how you are becoming part of it and how your network can gain awareness and lend support.


Erika Knerr, Publisher
New Observations
October 21, 2014

Listening to earlier calls left by thinkers like Giorgio Agamben or Jean-Luc Nancy, in her volume, we are seeking to read what a "call" and an "addressee" are in our experiences in art today. Because as one philosopher said, "our coming was expected on Earth" – recalling humanities relationship with it as well as relations between, parent and child, teacher and student, and the unknowable or posthumous friend."[Image: Issue 130 Cover, featuring Pedro A.H. Paxaio's red pencil drawing titled "P.P., 2014, from Imagines maiorum"]Short SummaryNew Observations  is a non-profit contemporary arts journal that is written, edited and published by the arts community in an expanded process. Each issue has a guest editor and a pertinent topic. The journal was founded in the early 1980's, covering New York's provocative art scenes at the time, expanding its horizons nation wide and internationally. Though the publication paused for 12 years, it happily relaunched with issue 129 in 2013.  Issue 130 is the second of the new series.     With this campaign we are searching for support to finance futures issues as well as general operating expenses.     Your support funds will allow us to print in a better quality environment and with the best materials with the most technologically advanced resouces. Offering a digital version is in development to reach an expanded audience through new media. Offering the public quality issues of New Observations, and being a conduit to present the visions of artists for a better future for our planet, is the mission of the journal, whose successful outcome depends on your help and support.(The four sections below expose in depth how, and the reasons why, you can help us publish our extraordinary new issue):1. What We Need & What You Get


The entire process of making an issue demands a minimum of $8,000. 

You will get an impressive volume (#130) containing new contributions by some of the most important thinkers and artists of our times, including a challenging group of emergent philosophers and artists opening new horizons for our experience in the problematic and uncertain time in which we are living.
We are now gathering funds to support forward activity. Your support will not only give us breathing room, but also will make you part of this fabulous venture. Also, depending on the kind of support, you can be mentioned in the masthead as a "Supporter," "Friend," or "Patron".



2. The Impact


According to our founder: “Every group of friends is unknowingly representing a complex universe of thought and that it is sufficient to have its members put on the page something, anything, for a whole world to be revealed.” We intend to maintain this maxim, by exploring in the pages of each issue, these complex universes of thought for thinking and living art and culture today. 

In particular, our newest issue hosts a crucial topic, "on the addressee," developed by the artist, thinker, and editor Pedro A.H. Paixão, who's complex persona asks: for whom does the poet and artist produce a poem or a work of art? But also, to whom does the philosopher
     write today? What is at stake in the calls that demand them to make work or share their thoughts, outside their professional roles?
We believe that you can engage with great commitment in being part of this genuine and generous enterprise, and that with every "new observation," every new emerging thought, every new sensible field, we propose, a new horizon line will be crossed together.

3. Risks & Challenges

To publish a non-profit publication means to live in a risky dimension and in a horizon of uncertainties. It means publishing without a precise date. That's why; above all, we are maintaining an annual issue. Rather than publishing on tight time schedules that produces insufficient
 results, we prefer to offer you the strongest outcome, by 
allowing each publication the conditions it needs to evolve to maturity.

Seeking the highest standards, we prefer to work under challenging conditions while engaging the most provocative artists and thinkers living today. This means a long maturation and dialogue with each guest editor, the authors and in understanding with transparency the topic we are working with.
Every new issue is a new field where we try to bring to your fore a pertinent and challenging aspect of contemporaneity, be it something forgotten or still missing, something hidden or too exposed, needing a new perspective to gain its proper dimension or value. We are measuring distances, searching new and old ways and modes of living, sources and new horizons that are keys to live well on our planet.


4. Other Ways You Can Help

We rely on you to share our campaign with your friends, followers, colleagues and those who would find your support of New Observations magazine of mutual interest.
Using the Indiegogo share tools helps you reach out to all your contacts, by word of mouth, or by word of web on networks like Facebook, Linkedin, Twitter, Email and in forums and chats. Please spread the news about what we are doing, how you are becoming part of it and how your network can gain awareness and lend support.
Erika Knerr, Publisher New ObservationsOctober 21, 2014

story:
PREORDER GRAVURE #7!

This is the only place you can preorder Gravure #7!

Just pledge $30 and it will be delivered right to your door, hot off the press!

-------



SUPPORT GRAVURE’S EXPANSION

Gravure's mission is to provide a sophisticated, independent venue to showcase vanguard fashion, art, design, and culture, but it is more than just a magazine.  It is a community and a venue for collaboration, nurturing and promoting creative projects which otherwise might not be see the light of day.

We are now seeking the support of our readers in order to secure capital to bring Gravure to a whole new level of reach and sustainability.

We started Gravure as a personal project with no desire or profit motive.  What started as a simple desire for a magazine offering contributors the creative freedom to do great work has since grown into a much larger venue and a vital community of creatives in fashion, art, and design.

Now we are seeking capital to expand and secure the future of Gravure as a venue for great and important work, and to expand our reach and better support and promote our community of contributors.

Publishing Gravure has afforded us the honor of collaborating with some of the most talented people in the industry.  The work we have created with them has gone on to become acclaimed art books by major publishers, exhibitions and has launched careers.  

The first six print editions of the magazine, as well as five limited edition artist monographs have been produced without advertising support in order to ensure our creative integrity is maintained without having to answer to commercial interests.  

We are now extending our network to include new creative collaborations, establish new distribution partnerships, reach new readers, and acheive a higher level of sustainability, which is why we are asking for you to support and become part of the Gravure creative community.

 

  

WHAT GRAVURE NEEDS AND WHY

The main goal of our funding is to be able to do a significantly larger print run and expand distribution of Gravure.

Printing:  This is our single largest expense.  Printing costs just to get an edition onto the press are staggering, but the costs per copy drop dramatically when you print larger quantity.  Our past printing costs have run between $9,000 to $15,000 per issue for limited editions of 1000 to 2000 pieces.  We print in the USA, because it affords us better quality since we can oversee the printing process by going on press and it also supports our economy domestically.  We’d like to at least triple our print run to reach more people.

Distribution:  Most magazines make the bulk of their revenue through advertising, not through magazine sales.  Distributors take 45-55% of the cover price as their commission, which means higher per-issue costs make any profit impossible.  Increasing our print run would mean lower per-issue costs, which makes Gravure more economically sustainable so we can print future editions, keep creating work, and keep promoting our contributors.

Production Costs:  As with virtually all independent magazines, ALL of our contributors offer their time, expertise, and passion for free, even going out of pocket to create the work.  They do this because, as much time, expense, and effort they put into creating the work, they know we put just as much work into making sure their work looks as good as it can, and making sure as many people see it as possible.  We’d like to be able to change the norm of independent publishing and offer budgets for our contributors to keep creating their work.  Any funds left over after printing and distribution would be used for this purpose.

  

 

WHAT YOU GET

As a token of our gratitude, we are offering various limited edition pieces and one-of-a-kind works of art by our contributors.  All supporters will be included in future Gravure offers, events, and promotions, and will become part of the Gravure creative community.

 

WHY SHOULD YOU SUPPORT GRAVURE

When you support Gravure, you are supporting an entire community of artists.  Every dollar given helps our contributors to create significant work which would otherwise not have a platform on which to be seen, and supports us in our efforts to showcase and offer exposure to various artists, both established and up-and-coming.

 

ADDITIONAL WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Share on Facebook, Tweet, blog, email, and tell your friends and family about Gravure’s campaign!  Even if you are unable to offer money, any effort you can make to let people know is a massive help.

 

 

PLEDGE PRIZES:

 

PRE-ORDER GRAVURE #7 ($30)

You will be among the first to receive Gravure Issue #7.  The issue will ship in time for New York Fashion Week in February 2013.

 

GRAVURE #3, LAST COPIES AVAILABLE ($75)

Includes “Nesting Instinct” by Jenny Gage + Tom Betterton

 

 

GRAVURE #1, NUMBERED EDITIONS 1-5 ($100)

Cover: Karen Elson photographed by Ellen von Unwerth

 

JULIE VERHOEVEN POSTER, “NITTY GRITTY”  ($200)

Original artwork by Julive Verhoeven commissioned for Gravure #2, 24” x 36”

10 Available

 

DEANNE CHEUK POSTER, “MAGGIE” ($200)

Original artwork by Deanne Cheuk commissioned for Gravure #3, 24” x 36”

3 Available (two untrimmed with printer’s edge print)

 

MATTHIAS VRIENS-MCGRATH POSTER “FREE LOVE” ($200)

Original artwork by Matthias Vriens-McGrath commissioned for Gravure #2, 24” x 36”

10 Available

 

 

 

JENNY GAGE + TOM BETTERTON POSTER “NESTING INSTINCT” ($200)

Original artwork by Jenny Gage + Tom Betterton commissioned for Gravure #3, 24” x 36”

2 available, Unpublished Limited Edition Piece, 24” x 36”

 

FULL SET OF GRAVURE, ISSUES 1-6 ($450)

5 Available

 

FULL SET OF GRAVURE, ISSUES 1-6 plus a 16”x20” Print by a Gravure contributor TBD, artwork from Gravure #7 ($900)

3 Available

 

FULL PAGE ADVERTISEMENT IN GRAVURE ($2,000)

For the first time ever, we are willing to open the pages of Gravure to our biggest supporters.  A pledge of $2500 buys you a single-page advertisement with prime placement (Back Cover, Inside Page 1, Inside Last Page, on a first-come, first-served basis).

3 Available

 

CATEGORY EXCLUSIVE ISSUE SPONSORSHIP ($7,500)

Double Page Spread advertisement in prime placement (Back Cover, Front Page 1, Back Inside).  Purchase of all three pledge prizes by a single supporter ($7,500) ensures category-exclusive issue sponsorship.

1 Available (Purchase all three of the above prize)

story:
Short Summary

Financial District Neighborhood Opposed to the IMMINENT relation of the NYC Dept of Probation to 66 John Street:

  • We are residents, students, and business owners in the Financial District.
  • We are seeking to preserve our residential neighborhood and, protect our children and schools, after investing so much in FiDi over the years.
  • A Probation "Adult Court" where "people with actual criminal records go every day" is not suitable for ANY RESIDENTIAL NEIGHBORHOOD.

Funds will be used to file a legal challenge to the City of New York's ill-conceived decision to move the Probation Department's "Adult Court" operations into our residential neighborhood and to convince the City to keep the DOP facility in the Civic Center where it belongs.

What We Need & What You Get

We are working to raise $50,000 to stop the City's move, which could take place any time in the coming weeks:

  • Lawyers fees and court costs
  • Public relations / media outreach
  • Local loobbying of elected officials

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Call and write Mayor Bloomber's Office and those of other elected officials.
  • Sign our on-line petition at http://www.ipetitions.com/petition/financial-district-against-nyc-dept-of-probation
  • Ask your friends and neighbors to become involved in any way they can!

story:
Paradiso is a live production by Stacy Scibelli and Rachel Fainter featuring aerial acrobatics, opera, dance, and more.  It will be an unconventional interpretation of the third book of The Divine Comedy, in which Dante recounts his ascension through Heaven.  Paradiso will be among the first artist-produced shows at The Slipper Room, a result of their up-and-coming artist-in-residence program.

The Slipper Room is best known for its edgy burlesque performances and variety shows.  The new artist-in-residence program is designed to broaden their concept as an experimental theater and to invite new perspectives into their weekly lineup.  At the same time, visual artists get a unique opportunity to produce a performance in a gorgeous LES theater.  We are raising funds for this production in hopes that the success of this show will generate interest in the Slipper Room's artist-in-residence program, and in turn will make it available to other visual artists in the future who wish to work in the medium of stage production. 

Stacy Scibelli and Rachel Fainter are both New York-based visual artists.  Stacy works primarily in fabrics, designing wearable, interactive art that is both sculpturesque and rich with social commentary.  Rachel is largely a 2-D artist, producing dissonant paintings that explore themes of lust, shame, and memory, but more recently has begun producing live shows.  This will be the first opportunity for these two artists to collaborate on a production in a Manhattan theater, bringing together their respective areas of expertise to create this distinctive performance.

Paradiso is perhaps the least familiar chapter of The Divine Comedy, following The Inferno and Purgatory.  Paradiso is the reward; the 'happy ending' to the unpleasant tale of the other two places. The medieval text is surprisingly abstract considering its Ptolemaic/geocentric views based on religion, alchemy, astrology, and witchcraft.  It is complex, divergent, and at times, psychedelic, with glittering and extraordinary imagery of spirits and celestial bodies.  This performance will stay loyal to that aspect of the text, transforming this piece of ancient literature into a brilliant spectacle of light and action.  

The money raised with this campaign will go toward custom-making costumes, designing stage sets, and compensating performers and stage crew.  We hope to raise enough to be able to run Paradiso for four nights beginning in October.  The success of this production will generate more buzz about and support for the artist-in-residence program.  And the more momentum this program gains, the more experimental shows patrons will have to look forward to, and a more established program for future artists to participate in.

Please donate to help raise money for this production as well as to get this unique and incredible program off the ground. It's a win-win for artists and patrons alike!  As a 'thank you' for your support, please check out our perks! (see images below).  If you are unable to donate money, we are also accepting donations in the form of fabric, makeup, glitter, and any other materials for the making of costumes and stage sets.  Please contact rfainter@gmail.com if you would like to donate materials.  Please spread the word!

THANK YOU, THANK YOU!  


Visit our websites:

http://stacyascibelli.com/

www.rachelfainter.com

 

 

 



Map of Heaven Screen Print ($15+)
8 x 10"
Screen print on watercolor paper

 

 

Hand-colored Doré Etching ($25)
8 1/2 x 11"
Inkjet print colored with watercolor, colored pencil and glitter
(Featuring Beatrice and the lamb of God)

  

 

Hand-painted Eagle of Justice Sculpture ($75+)
8" tall
Plaster and acrylic (including metallic, fluorescent and phosphorescent) sculpture
(with glo-in-the-dark eyes!)

story:
about illuminoidal arts

illuminoidal arts is an art studio and gallery on the Art Exchange row on 3rd St. in Long Beach, California. Since opening in January of 2012, illuminoidal arts has been the storefront studio of ArtX resident artist Leah C. Dixon, whose color-drenched work includes digital painting, ink works on paper, and abstract animation.

In addition to Leah's studio operations, the front window area is devoted to showcasing a different blend of art each month. As part of the ongoing Second Saturday events in Downtown Long Beach, illuminoidal arts has exhibited the work of a wide range of artists including Alex Schaefer, Jim Caron, Lethargic Artist, Dave Van Patten, Douglas Alvarez, Bill Dambrova, Daniel Rolnik, Lisa Derrick, John Kilduff, Johnny Naked, Vicky Barkley, Snow Mack, Juan Sanchez Diaz, Jen Shakti, Shahidd Jaleel Al-Askari, Tamara Guion, and Julie Scott.

how you can help us & what's in it for you.

The space at Art Exchange is the lynchpin of our operations. Access to the studios is granted to artists for a small but significant monthly donation. Between the monthly donation, utilities, the cost of art supplies, and other studio necessities, we are facing a small budget shortfall for 2014. The sooner we can secure the funding we need to stay open, the sooner we can get back to focusing all our time and attention on making and showcasing art!

Donations as small as $25 get a piece of art or photography from the illuminoidal arts grab bag, which includes prints and originals by over a dozen artists! Donors at the $50 level and up can request a specific artist from the grab bag - contact us for the full list!

the difference that will make for us

If we meet our modest campaign goal of $3000, that will stabilize our cash flow and allow us to pull the trigger on several new projects including:
  • the long-needed washout sink (our current sink is barely big enough to wash hands in) that we can rig from a wall spigot
  • production of the 'fruit roll up' prints - a unique specialty of resident artist Leah C. Dixon
  • more guest artists and more fun group art shows like Meme Democracy, Appetite: Tasting Hunger & Desire, POLY • CHROME, and Hazy Sunshine: Dispatches from SoCalistan.


from MEME DEMOCRACY: art by Vicki Barkley, Bill Dambrova, and Carol Powell

If we don't make the full $3000, we will use whatever funds raised to keep our studio operations and rotation of art programming going for as long as we can in the ArtX space.

If we make anything significantly over $3000, we will put that into material upgrades for the studio, such as a newer projector (to replace the 10-year-old one currently in use), improved floating walls, or materials for the creation of new works. Every dollar given will be spent for art's sake!

other ways you can help

  • share this with your art-loving friends
  • come see us for Second Saturdays or Third Thursdays
  • call us at 562 888 1523 for a private showing and studio tour

ArtX space.If we make anything significantly over $3000, we will put 
that into material upgrades for the studio, such as a newer projector 
(to replace the 10-year-old one currently in use), improved floating 
walls, or materials for the creation of new works. Every dollar given will be spent for art's sake!other ways you can help

come see us for Second Saturdays or Third Thursdays
call us at 562 888 1523 for a private showing and studio tour

story:
Opportunities for self expression and creativity are essential to a good quality of life. A group of artists I met in Uganda recognized this and began sharing their skills and their paints and brushes with kids in the neighborhood. It was informal at first. The kids would show up at James Nsamba's tiny studio every morning, brimming with energy and curiosity.  James and Farouk Mukwaya would hand out paper and paint and colored pencils...then give the kids some basic lessons in how to use art materials to express ideas and feelings..

Gradually we got more organized. We call ourselves Uganda Art Consortium. We started a website, ugandart.com, and we're part of Kisa Foundation USA, a 501 (c) (3) charity.

We now hold two or three workshops every year, attended by hundreds of children where they learn painting, drawing and jewelry making. We have 8 adult artists who volunteer as teachers. The kids become energetic and excited as they see their visions take shape on paper and canvas. They gradually become more confident, eager to speak out, proud of what they can do

Daily life can be grim for children in Namungona, a slum neighborhood on the outskirts of Kampala. Many are orphans...without a stable home life, steady school or even a steady diet. Many kids have to work to help support their families...hauling water, tending to their Mom's vegetable stand, or weeding the garden. They miss school because of work, or because the families can't afford the fees. School itself is pretty strict and regimented. There's a lot of rote learning, little chance for ideas or creativity.

The schools do the best they can with limited resources, but there's scant music, art, or literature in the curriculum. Our workshops help fill this cultural gap in children's lives.

Now we're hoping to build a small permanent art center in the community where we can hold classes, store materials, and have a gallery to display what the children have accomplished. With a gallery, we can attract tourists. The kids can sell their artwork to help support their families, and buy materials for the workshops. Having our own place is an essential step for us to improve and expand our outreach to Ugandan children through art.

The money we raise through Indiegogo will be used to buy or rent a small piece of land. Then, with many volunteers, we'll build a building ourselves, with recycled roofing sheets and bricks we make ourselves.

story:
Hello! My name is Corina Cîrlig (Korina Kyrlig) and I am from the Republic of Moldova. My basic occupation is related to my hobby – fine arts. I specialize in pencil portraits, but I am paying increasing attention to acrylic and oil paintings. During the last five years, since I started practicing drawing and painting, I made more than 200 pencil portraits and 6 acrylic and oil paintings of different sizes.

So, I belive that the most useful thing you cand do for people and for yourself is the thing you like and you can do best. To materialize this idea, I need help of people who understand my intention, and most important of all, who belive that fine arts are an important part of our day by day life. That’s why I started this crowdrising campaign, in hope that you will help me to find the money necessary to start working serious in this domain.

Firts of all, from money that I hope that I will raise through this campaign I, will arrange a workshop, vital for my further activityes, and will buy high quality utensiles (from pencils and paints, to canvases, eases and proper lights), vital for a relevant artistical result.

10.000 USD will be enough for a good start and will help me concertrate on the artistic work, but most important of all, will help me to promote my artworks on national and international scale.

To understand my artistic conception, you can visit my facebook page, and if you think my works are valuable, and you belive in my fine arts future, feel free to share my paintings and portraits and to spread the word about this campaign.

Thank you, and best regards!

Corina Cîrlig

story:
‘Bubblicious’ is a sculpture of geometric metal bubbles! Complex pieces interconnect to make a foam structure--a form common in nature. Foam structures are found in the arrangement of galaxies throughout space, the top your latté, and may be the source of cellular life on our planet!
An ambient flame will burn within the art piece providing light, heat and a focal point for participants to socialize. If you're lucky, you might get to push the button for the fire poofer (no bubbles will be harmed). Don't have foam-o! Help Reema get Bubblicious to the playa!

story:
Introduction
Two years ago Christina Battle and Adán De La Garza returned to Denver after being gone for just under a year. Living in different cities, they realized Denver had the potential for the creation of the artistic space and culture they valued. When they started in 2013, they didn’t anticipate the sudden hike in available warehouse space which has prevented them from obtaining a localized venue for Nothing To See Here. After looking at literally more than one hundred spaces, the decision to attempt a more nomadic approach for their exhibitions was adapted. A year and a half later, after several venue changes and exhibition tours, the push for a physical space has become more dire if NTSH wants to continue on.

Up until now NTSH has been entirely self-funded and although we wish we could continue following the same model, we have come to realize that the sustainability of our continued programming is unlikely without some additional support. We are also eager to realize our initial programming goals of curating and presenting longer term exhibitions, panel discussions, workshops, residencies and live performances, something that will only be possible with a small programming budget and access to consistent flexible space.


This is where we sit today, the possibility of obtaining a physical space would allow for more consistent programing and opportunities for artists in and outside of the Denver area, a chance to work with and support other Denver-based artist run endeavours, as well as contributing to the cultural capitol of Colorado.

Funds raised in this campaign will go toward renting a physical space for NTSH as well as a modest programming budget for the year.  


www.nothingto-seehere.com


About Nothing To See Here
Dedicated to exhibiting contemporary media art in Denver, Nothing To See Here is the collaborative art project of Christina Battle + Adán De La Garza offering a home for under represented artistic mediums including: Sound, Performance, Installation, Film and Video. By highlighting strong media artworks being made in Denver; exposing the Denver community to artists working outside of the region; and remunerating artists for their work, Nothing To See Here fills a void in Colorado's Contemporary Art scene. As collaborating artists, one of our goals is to create a stronger context for our own works through research and exhibition as well as creating a community that is better versed in these often overlooked disciplines.

As an art project, Nothing To See Here is focused on discourses within contemporary art conversations, and allows us to see ways in which other artists from around the globe tackle similar concerns in their own practices. Curating other artists’ works is also a way to introduce Denver to what is happening in the greater contemporary art conversation. Previous exhibitions have tackled issues related to surveillance, the politics of sound, disaster, dominant culture, subculture, notions of failure, and the current interaction we have with the media.

As artists we’re dedicated to increasing the awareness of Denver-based artists outside of the region - individually and collaboratively we have toured local artist’s works to other communities in: New York; Arizona; New Mexico; Pennsylvania; Canada; Germany; and Mexico.

We are also dedicated to paying exhibition fees to the artists we curate, something that is sadly uncommon amongst other Denver arts organizations. To date, NTSH has been self-funded with all money made from the door of screenings going directly back to the artists we work with. The ability to have a small amount of capital on hand would give us more flexibility in developing our exhibitions contributing to: screening costs, promotion, the publication of program notes, allow for the incorporation of live performances and a permanent exhibition space. We are strong, consistent contributors to the art community of Denver and are invested in expanding these contributions into the future.


Currently, we're looking for a permanent home that will allow for monthly screenings, exhibitions, music performances, and events, creating a converging point for our local arts community.

Thank you for your support! With your help we hope to continue working to build a stronger foundation for art in Denver and to continue to enrich the Denver Art community as a whole. Your help would be instrumental in pushing our project forward. If you’re unable to contribute funds we could still use your support! Share this campaign with your friends, come out to our events (which are always Pay What You Can) and keep supporting artist run culture in Denver!

Our Goal
Our goal is to raise $20,000 from this campaign that will help secure a space, contribute to screening costs, promotion, the publication of program notes, and allow for the incorporation of live performances.

Surpassing our goal would allow us to expand on our current exhibition plans allowing for a greater number of exhibitions, installations, and a stronger ability to invite artists to perform in Colorado from other regions.


A fundraiser resulting in less than our goal would still allow Nothing To See Here to continue its presence in the Denver art community. In this case, funds will go toward future programming with the potential of supporting temporary pop up exhibition space rentals.


Details About Nothing To See Here’s Programming
Active since early 2014, Nothing To See Here has curated and organized fourteen events to date: The TV is With Us (2/22/14); LOUD!!! (4/5/14); Grim New World (5/24/14); We Know You Are Watching (6/22/14); From Deep (8/16/14); it’s not a phase (9/20/14); title goes here (11/8/2014); Grim New World (21/12/14) at Think Tank in Tucson, Arizona; Inextinguishable Fire at Dikeou Collection (2/21/15); We Know You Are Watching (3/22/15) at Sugar City in Buffalo, NY; Denver ≥ Denver (3/24/15) at Regional Support Network in Toronto; LOUD!!! (3/25/15) at Pleasure Dome in Toronto; and CESSPOOL OF LOVE (5/29/15) in Denver; Denver ≥ Denver  (6/11/15) at Casa Maauad in Mexico City; and Denver ≥ Denver  (9/3/15) at Dikeou Collection in Denver.

We have been written about in Denver Westword here,here and here* as well as on Theresa Anderson’s Contemporary Art Blog. Specific details about each of our events can be found online: www.nothingto-seehere.com


*hard links to articles:
http://www.westword.com/2014-04-03/calendar/loud-and-proud/
http://blogs.westword.com/showandtell/2014/04/christina_battle_and_adan_de_l.php
http://www.westword.com/2014-06-19/calendar/say-cheese/
http://theresaandersonart.com/christina-battle-and-adan-de-la-garzas-grim-new-world/

Related Links:

http://www.cbattle.com
http://www.adandelagarza.com
