story:
Come Discover the Musical Intervals with Us and Austin, TX

  • Pythagoras (and Austinites) Discovering Musical Intervals
  • Flex Space Gallery at Pump Project
  • Austin, TX
  • September 7-16, 2012
  • Opening Night Reception: Friday, September 7, 2012

We are Jessica Nixon and Andy Tang from Orchestrated Occurrences, a new collaborative art partnership in Austin, TX. Our funding campaign is raising money for an Austin community art event based on the story of Pythagoras discovering the perfect musical intervals. Pythagoras heard by chance the sounds of hammers striking an anvil at a smithy, which corresponded to the same intervals he had been studying.

Pythagoras's discovery and the icon of the musical blacksmith have been familiar tropes in history since Ancient Rome and Greece, referenced in literary, musical, and visual arts. Modern scholars, though, have deemed the story as a fabrication and a legend, with the most recent unique interpretation from the 1600s. Our community event to showcase showcasing Austin-area artists' interpretations of the story will be the first update in 400 years. It is truly an historic event, and we want Austinites to discover the musical intervals with us.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The cost of this 10-day event is for the gallery space, the opening and closing reception; and for the materials of the sound installations we're building to let people play the intervals:

  • gallery space; renting pavillion tent(s), tables, chairs for reception
  • performers singing a Renaissance piece based on the intervals
  • PA and sound equipment rental
  • wood, sheet metal, wire, glass, PVC pipe tubes, string, rope
  • screws, nails, glue, duct tape, paint, paintbrushes

Perks include buttons and stickers, fabric patches, pieces of our sound installations, silk-screened posters, and other commemorative items!

 

The Impact

  • The most recent major interpretation about Pythagoras's discovery was by Marin Mersenne, a French scholar in the 1600s! Since then, new, unique interpretations have been stagnant, until now. . .
  • This community event is a historic that lets the city of Austin discover the intervals and interpret the story for itself.
  • The sound demonstrations we're building allow people to play the intervals, and to hear the familiarity of these sounds to the music they hear everyday!
  • We are inviting Austin-area artists to create a multisensory and interactive experience in their creations based on the story.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Submit artwork! More information can be found at our website: www.pythagorasatx.com
  • Like us on Facebook.
  • Spread the word! This event can't be possible without your help!

story:
Short Summary

Element 11's theme this year is Labyrinth. We are building a castle effigy with a classical seven-circuit labyrinth wrapped around it. The walls of this labyrinth will be lit with heavy-duty weatherproof LED rope lights. Help us fund these lights, for use this year and at Element 11 in the future! We are also raising funds for rope light for Center Camp. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are pricing out single-color and RGB-color-changing rope light. In return for sponsoring us, if you so desire, you will get a certificate to bring to Element 11 in July to be body-paint "branded" by the fabulous Minotaur! At a $200 or higher level of sponsorship you may choose to receive one of Alice Toler's artisan LED lights (tabletop version). 

The Impact

It's time to step up to the next level at Element 11. We are a powerhouse of a regional, and we want to show this to all comers! Being able to spectacularly light our Effigies and our Center Camp now and in future has been a big goal of ours. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us get the word out about this campaign, and come out to our Volunteer Vitalization event on April 27 to become a registered volunteer. You make Element 11 an amazing experience every year!

story:
ABOUT THE PROJECT

Planning for Protest is a publication and exhibition about spaces of protest.

The ongoing financial crisis and other global events have recently inspired large-scale protests across the globe, re-igniting debate around the relationship between citizens and public space. 

This exhibition asks twelve teams of architects and designers to respond to the crisis with proposals that address the conflictual motives behind spaces of protest in their own city.

WHO ARE WE

Ben Allen, James Bae and Ricardo Gomes of KWY (www.k-w-y.org), Shannon Harvey of Public Address (www.P-U-B-L-I-C.com) and Adam Michaels, Project Projects (www.projectprojects.com)

12 teams, 12 cities, 12 proposals:

Antonas Office (Athens), Studio Miessen (Berlin), studioBasar (Bucharest), Cluster (Cairo), Culturstruction (Dublin), Superpool (Istanbul), Ateliermob (Lisbon), public works with Isaac Marrero-Guillamón (London), Ecosistema Urbano (Madrid), Srdjan Jovanović Weiss / NAO (New York), PioveneFabi with 2/A + PA (Rome), and Vapor 324 (São Paulo).

WHAT YOU ARE HELPING FUND

We have been selected as an Associated Project of the 2013 Lisbon Architecture Triennale. In order to present the project in Lisbon, we need to raise 8,000 EUR.

Funding will support:

1) Exhibition — installation in Lisbon from Septemeber 12 through December 15, 2013.

2) Public Conversations — 3 conversations with participants and guests will provide a public forum to discuss the ideas presented.

3) Publication — designed by Project Projects, the publication is also a portable exhibition that grows to incorporate new material from every new city in which it is presented. 

4) Website — featuring exhibition materials, transcipts of conversations, and ongoing updates on protest spaces around the globe.

THE PERKS

1) A copy of the publication/portable exhibition

2) A super-cool tote bag (perfect for carrying the publication)

3) Your very own set of miniature "Z-Blocks" by Srdjan Jovanović Weiss / NAO

All organizers and participants have donated 100% of their time and services to this project. If we don’t reach our goal, your funds will still support the exhibition and public conversations directly.

OTHER WAYS TO SUPPORT

Please visit us www.planningforprotest.org, which will be updated regularly throughout the course of the exhibition, and ‘like’ us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/PlanningForProtest

Ben Allen, James Bae and Ricardo Gomes of KWY (www.k-w-y.org), Shannon Harvey of Public Address (www.P-U-B-L-I-C.com) and Adam Michaels, Project Projects (www.projectprojects.com)
12 teams, 12 cities, 12 proposals:
Antonas Office (Athens), Studio Miessen (Berlin), studioBasar (Bucharest), Cluster (Cairo), Culturstruction (Dublin), Superpool (Istanbul), Ateliermob (Lisbon), public works with Isaac Marrero-Guillamón (London), Ecosistema Urbano (Madrid), Srdjan Jovanović Weiss / NAO (New York), PioveneFabi with 2/A + PA (Rome), and Vapor 324 (São Paulo).
WHAT YOU ARE HELPING FUND
We have been selected as an Associated Project of the 2013 Lisbon Architecture Triennale. In order to present the project in Lisbon, we need to raise 8,000 EUR.
Funding will support:
1) Exhibition — installation in Lisbon from Septemeber 12 through December 15, 2013.
2) Public Conversations — 3 conversations with participants and guests will provide a public forum to discuss the ideas presented.
3) Publication — designed by Project Projects, the publication is also a portable exhibition that grows to incorporate new material from every new city in which it is presented. 
4) Website — featuring exhibition materials, transcipts of conversations, and ongoing updates on protest spaces around the globe.
THE PERKS
1) A copy of the publication/portable exhibition
2) A super-cool tote bag (perfect for carrying the publication)
3) Your very own set of miniature "Z-Blocks" by Srdjan Jovanović Weiss / NAO
All organizers and participants have donated 100% of their time and services to this project. If we don’t reach our goal, your funds will still support the exhibition and public conversations directly.
OTHER WAYS TO SUPPORT
Please visit us www.planningforprotest.org, which will be updated regularly throughout the course of the exhibition, and ‘like’ us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/PlanningForProtest

story:
SceneSelection is a cooperation between us, Hanrie van Heerden and Kristine Kronje, both independently practising artists from South Africa.
We were accepted to attend the Nes Artist Residency in Skagaströnd, Iceland during November 2010 which we regard as a significant opportunity in terms of potential cultural exchange. It is not a paid residency, so we need all the funding we can get! We believe very strongly in our work and especially this project and guarantee that you will not be left “empty minded”. Our work has a performative quality to it and depends greatly on the audience as participators – one of the reasons why we have much to share with those who support us.
SceneSelection relies on a synthesis between our individual
artistic concerns. Firstly, we notice a universal underlying desire or yearning for a less complicated life and through our practice based research we aim to explore what such a yearning entails and implicates globally. The aim of our project is ultimately to generate an awareness of this underlying yearning by using artistic practice as a means of research through interaction and a sustained interchange of cultural and personal ideas.
Although the project wil formally take place in the month of November, 2010, it already exists through a continual exchange of visual material, writing and ideas between us, currently living on different continents. The project will also continue through exhibitions or events in South Africa and possibly other Nordic countries following our stay as artists in residence.

story:
My Story

Hello, my name is Tom Baskeyfield, I am a student on the MA Art and Environment course at University College Falmouth, Cornwall, UK. I moved down to Cornwall from Macclesfield in Cheshire with my wife and our cat Haruki last September; I will be graduating from the course this September. Stemming from the 'Land Art' movement in the 60s and 70s the course seeks to position art in the real world. To move away from art for arts sake toward art for all's sake. We focus on ecological thinking and art as an ecological practice.


For my MA project I have been working with a field. 




(This and all following images with accompanying text are from the design layout of 'Of Time in a Field')


The Field / Why a Field?


Sitting on the banks of the Penryn River, 'Little Beach' as it is known, is an old arable field. Barley grows from its soil at present, gleaming yellow; one month to go until harvest. But when I first set foot on its soil, chunky brown earth is all there was. How it has changed over these few months. It is a small field, just under three acres, but it is clearly old, perhaps ancient. Crumbling Cornish hedges and tall oaks separate it from the adjoining land. 




I have spent the last ten months going to this field. The exposed earth and welcoming space attracted me to it at first, but a deeper desire to be there came from an interest in the land and our relationship to it. Fields are synonymous with the British landscape and they are integral to our lives yet they are perhaps somewhat over looked. What actually happens in a field over the course of a year? What lives live out and narratives present themselves? What can we learn about ourselves and the way we live today through consciously spending sustained time in one place?




Through my time with Little Beach I have seen it transform from a sodden, chunky orangey-brown expanse of space to a churned up medley of soil and stone, to a brown desert dotted with a carpet of young green shoots of barley, to an almost impenetrable thatching of coarse mature plants in their last few weeks before harvest. I have sat in the rain, in the freezing temperatures of last winter and in the burning sun of this summer contemplating this place and its place, and many others like it, in the lives of us all. At times I have wondered what I was doing there, why was I standing there as rain tumbled from my head to the sodden mud under my feet, at others I found myself in ore of the place existing at all, that this was the link to our past, to settlement and sustainable life. And beyond the soil and stone, hedgerows and crops the field is also about the birds, insects, rabbits and other creatures that call it home, whose lives it also sustains. 




My Art - How Have I Responded to The Field?


Through the ten months that I have worked with Little Beach I have approached its many faces in a number of ways. Walking, writing, photography and video are the main methods that make up my artistic practice. Earlier in the year I set up a blog to host my writing and photography about Little Beach. You can see that here: www.tothefield.blogspot.com


I have also created an online portfolio which contains more photographs and a film I made this year called Contemplating the Birth of a Field. You can see that here: www.tombaskeyfield.carbonmade.com




So why Have I set up This Campaign?


As a record of my time in the field, and as a way of presenting and sharing my experiences with others I am in the process of compiling my writing and photography into a book - Of Time in a Field. The book will be around 160 pages long, black and white with full colour front cover, paper back, 5" x 8" approx. I would like to print a very limited run of 100 books and this is where I'd like to share the project with you. To print 100 books I need £440 ($720) this I don't have. So I'm putting the idea out to you that if you are interested in what I have talked about above and would like to see the project come to fruition I am asking for you to pre-order a copy to make it happen. 


There will be 70 of the 100 books available for pre-order through this campaign as I would like to have a few available for the MA exhibition, and also, I intend to place at least 5 in public libraries in the local area and in the main library in my hometown, Macclesfield. I feel the real essence of the land is in community and I wish to share my experiences with the communities in which I'm part of.  



  

How it will work? What will you Receive for your role in the project?


There are three ways that you can contribute to the project. For £5 ($8)  you will receive a mounted and signed photograph taken by me over the past ten months in the field.  For £12 ($20) you will receive the above and a numbered copy of the book. For £15 ($24) you will receive the above and in addition the book will also be signed and your name will be printed inside as a thank you for your contribution. All contributions include postage and packaging to wherever you are in the world.


What if we don't raise enough?


If we don't raise the full amount, not to worry. I still intend to print 100 copies of the book, but I will do this in smaller quantities over a longer period of time. Of course everyone who has  contributed will receive their book, etc, as soon as the campaign has ended. I will keep you well informed.




Other Ways You Can Help

Please pass this on to any friends and family who you think would be interested.




Many thanks for taking the time to have a look,


Tom





Of Time in a Field

Of Time in a Field

story:
The Project

In the beginning of 2012, photographer Thomas Kellner received a surprising E-Mail from Yekaterinburg in the Russian Urals, to form a project with exhibition and book for the city’s anniversary in 2013, because Yekaterinburg was founded almost 300 years ago, by Georg Wilhem Henning, a Siegen Citizen. This was barely known and Thomas Kellner started his research and is now finalizing genius loci.


During the years of study Thomas Kellner began to work with pinhole cameras in the subject of art which built the basis for his approach he is following to the present day. In his early works experimenting with material, photographic methods and contents was crucial. It included building pinhole cameras himself in order to adopt them to the purpose he was aiming at.
The results reflect a diversity of styles and subjects. They range from multiple perspectives within one photograph over documentary to photograms. In this period he always printed full editions so that today there is a large number of a vintage print for later exhibitions.

At the end of the nineties then Thomas focused on the analogue camera and 35 mm film. He developed a visual language and method that deconstructs and constructs objects at the same time.
Now, since already 15 years, he is working in a worldwide unique style of contactsheets, photographing the object in numerous singular shots until in the end the object is visible in its entirety again. The film-material Thomas is using is transparent for the recipient as well because the single shots are assembled together as negatives. Therefore perforation, codification and numbers of the film-material are part of the positive.

“What I was viewing was not a single photograph but an entire orchestration of shots, with the format of the contact sheet serving to freeze and destabilize these atomistic particles at the same time.”
Kellner, T., Wendorf, R., 2008. All shook up. Thomas Kellner Photographs The Boston Athenaeum. Boston: Susan Morse Hilles Bicentennial Fund.  



genius loci Photobook


In 2013 Thomas Kellner photographed important companies and establishments in Siegerland and South-Westphalia in Germany and went several times to Russia to take pictures there from chosen regions and their industrial architecture.
These photographs will be published in the book “genius loci” to show the heretofore little-known connection between Siegen and the Russian Urals as well as the beauty of the respective industrial cultures. In the size of 12 x 10 inches and with approximately 120 pages the photo-book will tell us new and interesting facts about the industrial history of Siegen, the life of its native citizen Georg Wilhelm Henning and the work of Thomas Kellner as an artist. Approximately 30 images will portray the industrially important enterprises as representatives of their regions to show their connection to steel and metal.
Thomas Kellner is looking forward to familiarize the two regions, Siegen and the Russian Urals, with each other through this project both, economically and culturally, and to call the “genius loci” alias Georg Wilhelm Henning to mind.  
Thank you for your help making this book possible.

Book Details

Text: Essay by Artjem Berkovich, Dr. Andreas Bingener, Dr. Irina Chmyreva
Design: Marc Babenschneider, inspirit - graphicbureau
Photographs: approx. 30 in color
Size: approx. 12 x 10 inches
Retail price: 39.80 Euro
Publication date: 22 November 2013
Publisher: seltmann+söhne

Rewards


Pledge $10 or more

Receive acknowledgment in “genius loci” website and an invitation to the book launch in Siegen/Germany

Estimated delivery: Dec 2013

Pledge $50 or more

Received a signed copy of genius loci, acknowledgment on “genius loci” website and an invitation to the book launch in Siegen/Germany

Estimated delivery: Dec 2013

Add $29 USD to ship outside Germany

Pledge $100 or more

Receive a signed copy of my recent book “Houston we’ve had a problem”, a signed copy of “genius loci”, acknowledgment on genius loci website and an invitation to the book launch in Siegen/Germany

Estimated delivery: Dec 2013

Add $29 USD to ship outside Germany

Pledge $200 or more

82#02 Yekaterinburg, Cathedral on the Blood 2012 C-Print 22,7 x 42 cm

Receive a signed copy of the special edition print “Cathedral on the blood” (edition 100) available to indiegogo backers only; plus Receive a signed copy of my recent book “Houston we’ve had a problem”, a signed copy of “genius loci”, acknowledgment on genius loci website and an invitation to the book launch in Siegen/Germany

Estimated delivery: Dec 2013

Add $29 USD to ship outside Germany

Pledge $2,500 or more

82#20 Pervouralsk New Pipe Plant 2013 C-Print 91 x 59,5 cm / 36" x 24"

Limited 12

Receive the cover image of genius loci 36-by-24-inch limited-edition photograph, signed and numbered in an edition of 12+3, a signed copy of genius loci, acknowledgment on “genius loci” website and an invitation to the book launch in Siegen/Germany

Estimated delivery: Dec 2013

Add $300 USD to ship outside Germany


Thomas Kellner

Thomas Kellner was born in Bonn in 1966. He studied Art and Social Sciences at the University of Siegen and is working since 1997 as professional artist in the field of photography in Siegen. Exhibitions of his photographs have been mounted in galleries including London, Paris, Brasilia and New York. Museums, like the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston and the Museum of Modern Art Rio de Janeiro have already integrated his works in their compilation. Numerous exhibitions showed his photography in national and international venues. Important major projects of the last years were his works for the bicentenary anniversary of the Boston Athenaeum and the fifty-year-old anniversary of the capital Brasília.

seltmann+söhne

Formed in 2004, the name says it all. In close cooperation with the Seltmann printer company, established in 1870, two generations of printers and designers work hand in hand.

The goal is to make and publish books of the highest quality in printing technology, design and content. The focus of the publisher is on art and photo books.

Spread the Word!

After pledging your support, please help to spread the word about this project by sharing this link with your contacts.

Thank you for your support!

story:
Miles & Coltrane: Blue (.) by Concrete Generation

captures the energy of the 1950's, an era when America was rapidly changing. Jazz was the soundtrack of this era, and at the forefront of jazz music was trumpet blaring Miles Davis; and skillful saxophonist John Coltrane. They partnered soundscapes that would become the soundtrack to a social revolution.

Like Jazz, this stage production provides a unique experience each time and has "something new, always.” It is journey, through the lives of two of the most influential and controversial figures in jazz. Guided by award winning poets, musicians, dancers, and actors; we explore how they changed music and left a powerful legacy of jazz.

Your donation will help with the production and travel costs as we return to the Edinburgh International Fringe Festival !!!

Miles & Coltrane: Blue(.) by Concrete Generation runs from August 3 - 26, 2013 at C Venues Ediburgh, Scotland. 

 

Ways You Can Help

  1. Catch the show in Charlotte, NC May 29 - June 2, 2013 Duke Energy Theater at Spirit Square - 345 N College St  Charlotte, NC28202 

  2. Like our Facebook page and Follow us on Twitter @MCBlueOnTour check in for the latest updates 
  3. Party with us at our exclusive IndieGoGo Cast Party on June 2, 2013 at Poor Richards Book Shoppe 135 Brevard Court, Charlotte, NC 28202 

 

Miles & Coltrane: Blue (.) - Reviews & Press

"Every year at this time I discover a little gem or two... This year it was Miles & Coltrane: Blue(.) by Concrete Generation." -Retta Blaney, Life Upon the Sacred Stage, NYC

"A mesmerizing testament to the transcendence of Davis' and Coltrane's music. Miles & Coltrane: Blue is Like to going to church -almost." -Duffy Lewis, Charleston City Paper, Piccolo Spoleto

An intriguing production which evoked the spirits of Miles and Coltrane's work while portraying them as wildly different characters. Miles (is) the aloof scene stealer, fiercely proud of his hertiage, with Coltrane forever in search of his own inner salvation."  - Euan Andrews, Edinburgh Guide

In the great Miles Davis Quintets of the late 1950's, Davis was the foundation and the artitecture on trumpet while tenor saxophonist John Coltrane was the flame-throwe who filled the building with dazzling light. There's a marvelous dialogue between Sultan Omar El-Amin and Quentin Talley, who portray the two jazz titans, that beautifully articulates the yin yang of their musical chemistry... Miles & Coltrane: Blue (.), filled the stage with extensions of that alchemy." -Perry Tannenbaum, Creative Loafing 

Another great quality about the production is that while it is about jazz, the play itself is performed as a work of jazz. Onstage, the music -by The Stephen Gordon Group- for all intents and purposes, never stops playing. And if you look and listen closely, you'll notice moments when lines deliver from actors' mouth are intermingled with improvisation from the band; dialogue take the place of notes and performers become human instruments." - Carlton Hargro, QCityMetro

Miles & Coltrane: Blue (.) - Reviews & Press
"Every year at this time I discover a little gem or two... This year it was Miles & Coltrane: Blue(.) by Concrete Generation." -Retta Blaney, Life Upon the Sacred Stage, NYC
"A mesmerizing testament to the transcendence of Davis' and Coltrane's music. Miles & Coltrane: Blue is Like to going to church -almost." -Duffy Lewis, Charleston City Paper, Piccolo Spoleto 
An intriguing production which evoked the spirits of Miles and Coltrane's work while portraying them as wildly different characters. Miles (is) the aloof scene stealer, fiercely proud of his hertiage, with Coltrane forever in search of his own inner salvation."  - Euan Andrews, Edinburgh Guide 
In the great Miles Davis Quintets of the late 1950's, Davis was the foundation and the artitecture on trumpet while tenor saxophonist John Coltrane was the flame-throwe who filled the building with dazzling light. There's a marvelous dialogue between Sultan Omar El-Amin and Quentin Talley, who portray the two jazz titans, that beautifully articulates the yin yang of their musical chemistry... Miles & Coltrane: Blue (.), filled the stage with extensions of that alchemy." -Perry Tannenbaum, Creative Loafing  
Another great quality about the production is that while it is about jazz, the play itself is performed as a work of jazz. Onstage, the music -by The Stephen Gordon Group- for all intents and purposes, never stops playing. And if you look and listen closely, you'll notice moments when lines deliver from actors' mouth are intermingled with improvisation from the band; dialogue take the place of notes and performers become human instruments." - Carlton Hargro, QCityMetro
